theorem number_theory_122548 (m n : ‚Ñï) (hm : m > 0) (hn : n > 0)
    (h : ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.Icc n (n + m), i = 1000) :
    (m = 15 ‚àß n = 55) ‚à® (m = 24 ‚àß n = 28) ‚à® (m = 4 ‚àß n = 198) := by

informal_statement:
Let $\mathbf{v}$ and $\mathbf{w}$ be vectors such that
\[\text{proj}_{\mathbf{w}} \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -11 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find $\text{proj}_{-\mathbf{w}} (\mathbf{v})$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $\mathbf{v}$ and $\mathbf{w}$ be vectors such that
\[\text{proj}_{\mathbf{w}} \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -11 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find $\text{proj}_{-\mathbf{w}} (\mathbf{v})$. -/
theorem calculus_22314 {v w : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù}
  (hw : w ‚â† 0) (h : (v.1 * w.1 + v.2 * w.2) / (w.1 ^ 2 + w.2 ^ 2) = 2 ‚àß
  (v.1 * w.2 - v.2 * w.1) / (w.1 ^ 2 + w.2 ^ 2) = -11) :
  (v.1 * (-w.1) + v.2 * (-w.2)) / ((-w.1) ^ 2 + (-w.2) ^ 2) = 2 ‚àß
  (v.1 * (-w.2) - v.2 * (-w.1)) / ((-w.1) ^ 2 + (-w.2) ^ 2) = -11 := by

informal_statement: (4) Given the constant $a>0$, solve the equation $\log _{\sqrt{2}}(x-a)=1+\log _{2} x$ for $x$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (4) Given the constant $a>0$, solve the equation $\log _{\sqrt{2}}(x-a)=1+\log _{2} x$ for $x$ -/
theorem algebra_244114 (a : ‚Ñù) (ha : a > 0) (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x > a) :
    Real.logb (Real.sqrt 2) (x - a) = 1 + Real.logb 2 x ‚Üî
    x = 1 + Real.sqrt (2 + 1) := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

By adding all three equations, we get $7(x+y+z)=42$, from which $x+y+z=6$. Now we will sequentially subtract this equation from each equation in the system:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
3 x+2 y+2 z=13, \\
x+y+z=6
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow x=1 ;\left\{\begin{array}{l}
2 x+3 y+2 z=14 \\
x+y+z=6
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow y=2 ;\right.\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
2 x+2 y+3 z=15, \\
x+y+z=6
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow z=3 .\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: $(1 ; 2 ; 3)$.
informal_statement: 6.095. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}3 x+2 y+2 z=13, \\ 2 x+3 y+2 z=14, \\ 2 x+2 y+3 z=15 .\end{array}\right.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6.095. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}3 x+2 y+2 z=13, \\ 2 x+3 y+2 z=14, \\ 2 x+2 y+3 z=15 .\end{array}\right.$ -/
theorem algebra_187212 {x y z : ‚Ñù} (h1 : 3*x+2*y+2*z=13) (h2 : 2*x+3*y+2*z=14)
    (h3 : 2*x+2*y+3*z=15) :
    x=1 ‚àß y=2 ‚àß z=3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_187212 {x y z : ‚Ñù} (h1 : 3*x+2*y+2*z=13) (h2 : 2*x+3*y+2*z=14)
    (h3 : 2*x+2*y+3*z=15) :
    x=1 ‚àß y=2 ‚àß z=3 := by 
  have eq4 : y = x + 1 := by
    linarith
  have eq5 : z = x + 2 := by
    linarith
  have hx : x = 1 := by
    rw [eq4, eq5] at h1
    linarith
  have hy : y = 2 := by
    rw [hx] at eq4
    linarith
  have hz : z = 3 := by
    rw [hx] at eq5
    linarith
  exact ‚ü®hx, hy, hz‚ü©

soln_description:
[Solution] Let $x_{1}, x_{2}$ be the roots of the quadratic trinomial $x^{2} + m x + n$, and $x_{3}, x_{4}$ be the roots of the quadratic trinomial $x^{2} + p x + q$.

If these two pairs of roots are mutually separated, that is, $x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, x_{4}$ are real numbers, and one of $x_{3}, x_{4}$ is within the interval $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$, while the other is outside this interval.

Thus, there are two possible scenarios: either the differences $x_{3} - x_{1}, x_{3} - x_{2}$ have the same sign, and the differences $x_{4} - x_{1}, x_{4} - x_{2}$ have opposite signs; or the differences $x_{3} - x_{1}, x_{3} - x_{2}$ have opposite signs, and the differences $x_{4} - x_{1}, x_{4} - x_{2}$ have the same sign. In both cases, we have
$$\left(x_{3} - x_{1}\right)\left(x_{3} - x_{2}\right)\left(x_{4} - x_{1}\right)\left(x_{4} - x_{2}\right) < 0 .$$

Since $x_{1} + x_{2} = -m, x_{1} x_{2} = n$, we have
$$\begin{aligned}
\left(x_{3} - x_{1}\right)\left(x_{3} - x_{2}\right) & = x_{3}^{2} - \left(x_{1} + x_{2}\right) x_{3} + x_{1} x_{2} \\
& = x_{3}^{2} + m x_{3} + n, \\
\left(x_{4} - x_{1}\right)\left(x_{4} - x_{2}\right) & = x_{4}^{2} - \left(x_{1} + x_{2}\right) x_{4} + x_{1} x_{2} \\
& = x_{4}^{2} + m x_{4} + n .
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, inequality (1) can be rewritten as
$$\left(x_{3}^{2} + m x_{3} + n\right)\left(x_{4}^{2} + m x_{4} + n\right) < 0 .$$

Expanding the left side of the inequality, noting that
$$\begin{array}{l}
x_{3} + x_{4} = -p, x_{3} x_{4} = q \text{ and } \\
x_{3}^{2} + x_{4}^{2} = \left(x_{3} + x_{4}\right)^{2} - 2 x_{3} x_{4} = p^{2} - 2 q,
\end{array}$$

we have
$$\begin{aligned}
& \left(x_{3}^{2} + m x_{3} + n\right)\left(x_{4}^{2} + m x_{4} + n\right) \\
= & x_{3}^{2} x_{4}^{2} + m x_{3} x_{4}\left(x_{3} + x_{4}\right) + m^{2} x_{3} x_{4} + n\left(x_{3}^{2} + x_{4}^{2}\right) + m n\left(x_{3} + x_{4}\right) + n^{2} \\
= & q^{2} - m p q + m^{2} q + n\left(p^{2} - 2 q\right) - m n p + n^{2} \\
= & (n - q)^{2} + m q(m - p) + n p(p - m) \\
= & (n - q)^{2} + (m - p)(m q - n p) .
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, inequality (2) can be written as
$$(n - q)^{2} + (m - p)(m q - n p) < 0$$

This means that if the roots of the quadratic trinomials $x^{2} + m x + n$ and $x^{2} + p x + q$ are mutually separated, then the coefficients of these quadratic trinomials satisfy condition (3).
informal_statement:
5.63 Given that $m, n, p, q$ are real numbers. For the quadratic trinomials
$$x^{2}+m x+n \text { and } x^{2}+p x+q$$

to have real roots, and for the roots of one polynomial to be separated by the roots of the other polynomial
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5.63 Given that $m, n, p, q$ are real numbers. For the quadratic trinomials
$$x^{2}+m x+n \text { and } x^{2}+p x+q$$

to have real roots, and for the roots of one polynomial to be separated by the roots of the other polynomial -/
theorem algebra_601618 (m n p q : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àÉ x, x^2 + m * x + n = 0) (h‚ÇÇ : ‚àÉ x, x^2 + p * x + q = 0)
    (h‚ÇÉ : ‚àÄ x, x^2 + m * x + n = 0 ‚Üí (x^2 + p * x + q ‚â† 0)) :
    (n - q)^2 + (m - p) * (m * q - n * p) < 0 := by

soln_description:
We determine the smallest and largest three-digit perfect squares first.

Clearly, the smallest three-digit perfect square is $100=10^{2}$.

Now $\sqrt{1000} \approx 31.6$, so the largest perfect square less than 1000 is $31^{2}=961$ (since $31^{2}1000$ ).

Therefore, only the perfect squares between $10^{2}=100$ and $31^{2}=961$ have three digits, which means that exactly 22 three-digit positive integers are perfect squares.

ANSWER: (B)
informal_statement:
How many three-digit positive integers are perfect squares?
(A) 23
(B) 22
(C) 21
(D) 20
(E) 19
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- How many three-digit positive integers are perfect squares?
(A) 23
(B) 22
(C) 21
(D) 20
(E) 19 -/
theorem number_theory_276095 :
    Set.ncard {n : ‚Ñï | n ‚àà Finset.Icc 100 999 ‚àß ‚àÉ k, n = k^2} = 22 := by

soln_description:
$\triangle$ Multiply both sides of the equation by the conjugate of its left part

$$
\sqrt{9 x^{2}-12 x+11}+\sqrt{5 x^{2}-8 x+10}
$$

Since it does not turn into zero, we will obtain an equation equivalent to the given one. We will have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(9 x^{2}-12 x+11\right)-\left(5 x^{2}-8 x+10\right)= \\
& =(2 x-1)\left(\sqrt{9 x^{2}-12 x+11}+\sqrt{5 x^{2}-8 x+10}\right) \\
& (2 x-1)^{2}=(2 x-1)\left(\sqrt{9 x^{2}-12 x+11}+\sqrt{5 x^{2}-8 x+10}\right) \\
& (2 x-1)\left(2 x-1-\sqrt{9 x^{2}-12 x+11}-\sqrt{5 x^{2}-8 x+10}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider two cases.

1) Let $2 x-1=0$. Then $x=\frac{1}{2}$.
2) Let the expression in the second parentheses of the left part of the equation be equal to zero. We obtain a system of two equations with one unknown:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt{9 x^{2}-12 x+11}+\sqrt{5 x^{2}-8 x+10}=2 x-1 \\
\sqrt{9 x^{2}-12 x+11}-\sqrt{5 x^{2}-8 x+10}=2 x-1
\end{array}\right.
$$

From here

$$
\sqrt{5 x^{2}-8 x+10}=0, \quad 5 x^{2}-8 x+10=0
$$

But the last equation has no real roots.

Answer: $1 / 2$.
informal_statement:
397. Solve the equation:

$$
\sqrt{9 x^{2}-12 x+11}+\sqrt{5 x^{2}-8 x+10}=2 x-1
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 397. Solve the equation:

$$
\sqrt{9 x^{2}-12 x+11}+\sqrt{5 x^{2}-8 x+10}=2 x-1
$$ -/
theorem algebra_188259 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 ‚â§ 9 * x ^ 2 - 12 * x + 11) (hy : 0 ‚â§ 5 * x ^ 2 - 8 * x + 10) :
    Real.sqrt (9 * x ^ 2 - 12 * x + 11) + Real.sqrt (5 * x ^ 2 - 8 * x + 10) = 2 * x - 1 ‚Üî x = 1 / 2 := by

informal_statement: If three non-zero and distinct real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfy $\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} = \frac{2}{c}$, then $a, b, c$ are called harmonic; if they satisfy $a + c = 2b$, then $a, b, c$ are called arithmetic. Given the set $M = \left\{ x \mid |x| \leq 2013, x \in \mathbf{Z} \right\}$, and the set $P$ is a three-element subset of set $M$, i.e., $P = \left\{ a, b, c \right\} \subset M$. If the elements $a, b, c$ in set $P$ are both harmonic and arithmetic, then set $P$ is called a "good set". The number of different "good sets" is ___ ___.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def is_harmonic (a b c : ‚Ñù) := a ‚â† 0 ‚àß b ‚â† 0 ‚àß c ‚â† 0 ‚àß a ‚â† b ‚àß a ‚â† c ‚àß b ‚â† c ‚àß 1 / a + 1 / b = 2 / c
def is_arithmetic (a b c : ‚Ñù) := a ‚â† 0 ‚àß b ‚â† 0 ‚àß c ‚â† 0 ‚àß a ‚â† b ‚àß a ‚â† c ‚àß b ‚â† c ‚àß a + c = 2 * b

def M : Set ‚Ñ§ := {x | |x| ‚â§ 2013}

def P : Set (Fin 3 ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) := {p | ‚àÉ a b c : ‚Ñ§, p = ![a, b, c] ‚àß a ‚àà M ‚àß b ‚àà M ‚àß c ‚àà M ‚àß is_harmonic (a : ‚Ñù) (b : ‚Ñù) (c : ‚Ñù) ‚àß is_arithmetic (a : ‚Ñù) (b : ‚Ñù) (c : ‚Ñù)}

/- If three non-zero and distinct real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfy $\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} = \frac{2}{c}$, then $a, b, c$ are called harmonic; if they satisfy $a + c = 2b$, then $a, b, c$ are called arithmetic. Given the set $M = \left\{ x \mid |x| \leq 2013, x \in \mathbf{Z} \right\}$, and the set $P$ is a three-element subset of set $M$, i.e., $P = \left\{ a, b, c \right\} \subset M$. If the elements $a, b, c$ in set $P$ are both harmonic and arithmetic, then set $P$ is called a "good set". The number of different "good sets" is ___ ___. -/
theorem algebra_9213 :
    Set.ncard {p ‚àà P | p 0 ‚â† 0 ‚àß p 1 ‚â† 0 ‚àß p 2 ‚â† 0 ‚àß p 0 ‚â† p 1 ‚àß p 0 ‚â† p 2 ‚àß p 1 ‚â† p 2 ‚àß is_harmonic (p 0 : ‚Ñù) (p 1 : ‚Ñù) (p 2 : ‚Ñù) ‚àß is_arithmetic (p 0 : ‚Ñù) (p 1 : ‚Ñù) (p 2 : ‚Ñù)} = 1006 := by

soln_description:
Prove: Since $\frac{2 x}{y+z}+\frac{2 y}{z+x}+\frac{2 z}{x+y}-3$
$$\begin{aligned}
= & \left(\frac{2 x}{y+z}-1\right)+\left(\frac{2 y}{z+x}-1\right)+\left(\frac{2 z}{x+y}-1\right) \\
= & \frac{(x-y)-(z-x)}{y+z}+\frac{(y-z)-(x-y)}{z+x}+\frac{(z-x)-(y-z)}{x+y} \\
= & {\left[\frac{(x-y)}{y+z}-\frac{(x-y)}{z+x}\right]+\left[\frac{(y-z)}{z+x}-\frac{(y-z)}{x+y}\right] } \\
& +\left[\frac{(z-x)}{x+y}-\frac{(z-x)}{y+z}\right] \\
= & \frac{(x-y)^{2}}{(y+z)(z+x)}+\frac{(y-z)^{2}}{(z+x)(x+y)} \\
& +\frac{(z-x)^{2}}{(x+y)(y+z)} \\
\geqslant & 0
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, $\frac{x}{y+z}+\frac{y}{z+x}+\frac{z}{x+y} \geqslant \frac{3}{2}$.
informal_statement:
Example 1 Given that $x, y, z$ are positive real numbers, prove:
$$\frac{x}{y+z}+\frac{y}{z+x}+\frac{z}{x+y} \geqslant \frac{3}{2} \text {. }$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1 Given that $x, y, z$ are positive real numbers, prove:
$$\frac{x}{y+z}+\frac{y}{z+x}+\frac{z}{x+y} \geqslant \frac{3}{2} \text {. }$$ -/
theorem inequalities_598052 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z) :
    x / (y + z) + y / (z + x) + z / (x + y) ‚â• 3 / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_598052 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z) :
    x / (y + z) + y / (z + x) + z / (x + y) ‚â• 3 / 2 := by
  have h1 : 0 < x + y + z := by linarith
  have h3 : 0 < y + z := by linarith
  have h4 : 0 < z + x := by linarith
  have h5 : 0 < x + y := by linarith

  have h2 : x / (y + z) + y / (z + x) + z / (x + y) - 3 / 2 ‚â• 0 := by
    have h6 : x / (y + z) + y / (z + x) + z / (x + y) - 3 / 2 =
        (2 * x * (z + x) * (x + y) + 2 * y * (y + z) * (x + y) + 2 * z * (y + z) * (z + x) - 3 * (y + z) * (z + x) * (x + y))
          / (2 * (y + z) * (z + x) * (x + y)) := by
      field_simp
      ring
    rw [h6]
    have h7 : 0 < 2 * (y + z) * (z + x) * (x + y) := by positivity
    have h8 : 2 * x * (z + x) * (x + y) + 2 * y * (y + z) * (x + y) + 2 * z * (y + z) * (z + x) - 3 * (y + z) * (z + x) * (x + y) ‚â• 0 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (y - z), sq_nonneg (z - x),
        sq_pos_of_pos (show 0 < x by linarith), sq_pos_of_pos (show 0 < y by linarith), sq_pos_of_pos (show 0 < z by linarith),
        sq_nonneg (x + y - z), sq_nonneg (y + z - x), sq_nonneg (z + x - y)]
    apply div_nonneg
    linarith
    positivity
  linarith

soln_description:
„ÄêAnalysis„ÄëFrom the terms and their frequencies, we can consider completing the square, or we can use the mean inequality.
Solution Adding the three equations yields
$$
\begin{array}{l} 
x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}+x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+12-5 x y-5 y z-5 x z=0 \\
\Rightarrow\left(x^{2}-2\right)^{2}+\left(y^{2}-2\right)^{2}+\left(z^{2}-2\right)^{2}+ \\
\frac{5}{2}\left((x-y)^{2}+(y-z)^{2}+(z-x)^{2}\right)=0 \\
\Rightarrow x=y=z \\
\Rightarrow(x, y, z)=( \pm \sqrt{2}, \pm \sqrt{2}, \pm \sqrt{2}) .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
Example 7 Solve the system of equations: $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x^{4}+y^{2}+4=5 y z, \\ y^{4}+z^{2}+4=5 z x, \\ z^{4}+x^{2}+4=5 x y .\end{array}\right.$ $[6]$
(61st Czech and Slovak Mathematical Olympiad)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 7 Solve the system of equations: $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x^{4}+y^{2}+4=5 y z, \\ y^{4}+z^{2}+4=5 z x, \\ z^{4}+x^{2}+4=5 x y .\end{array}\right.$ $[6]$
(61st Czech and Slovak Mathematical Olympiad) -/
theorem algebra_199302 {x y z : ‚Ñù} (h‚ÇÄ : x^4 + y^2 + 4 = 5 * y * z) (h‚ÇÅ : y^4 + z^2 + 4 = 5 * z * x)
    (h‚ÇÇ : z^4 + x^2 + 4 = 5 * x * y) :
    (x, y, z) = (Real.sqrt 2, Real.sqrt 2, Real.sqrt 2) := by

informal_statement: Find all natural number solutions $n \in \mathbb{N}$ to the equation: $n^2 \cdot 2^{n^2} + 2 \log_2 n = n + 2^{n + 2^n}$.

theorem number_theory_4658 {n : ‚Ñï} {hn : 0 < n} :
    n ^ 2 * 2 ^ (n ^ 2) + 2 * logb 2 n = n + 2 ^ (n + 2 ^ n) ‚Üî n = 2 ‚à® n = 4 := by

soln_description:
5. $f(x)=c_{1} x+\frac{c_{2}}{x}\left(c_{1} „ÄÅ c_{2}\right.$ are arbitrary constants $)$.

For a fixed real number $a>1$ and a new variable $t$, in equation (1), take
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x=y=t ; x=\frac{t}{a}, y=a t ; \\
x=a^{2} t, y=t ; x=y=a t,
\end{array}
$$

to obtain the system of equations involving $f(t) „ÄÅ f\left(t^{2}\right) „ÄÅ f(a t) „ÄÅ f\left(a^{2} t^{2}\right)$:
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(t+\frac{1}{t}\right) f(t)=f\left(t^{2}\right)+f(1), \\
\left(\frac{t}{a}+\frac{a}{t}\right) f(a t)=f\left(t^{2}\right)+f\left(a^{2}\right), \\
\left(a^{2} t+\frac{1}{a^{2} t}\right) f(t)=f\left(a^{2} t^{2}\right)+f\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}}\right), \\
\left(a t+\frac{1}{a t}\right) f(a t)=f\left(a^{2} t^{2}\right)+f(1) .
\end{array}\right.
$$

From equations (2) and (3), eliminate $f\left(t^{2}\right)$ to get
$$
\left(t+\frac{1}{t}\right) f(t)-\left(\frac{t}{a}+\frac{a}{t}\right) f(a t)=f(1)-f\left(a^{2}\right) \text {. }
$$

From equations (4) and (5), eliminate $f\left(a^{2} t^{2}\right)$ to get
$$
\left(a^{2} t+\frac{1}{a^{2} t}\right) f(t)-\left(a t+\frac{1}{a t}\right) f(a t)=f\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}}\right)-f(1) \text {. }
$$

From the above two equations, eliminate $f(a t)$ to get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(\left(a t+\frac{1}{a t}\right)\left(t+\frac{1}{t}\right)-\left(\frac{t}{a}+\frac{a}{t}\right)\left(a^{2} t+\frac{1}{a^{2} t}\right)\right) f(t) \\
=\left(a t+\frac{1}{a t}\right)\left(f(1)-f\left(a^{2}\right)\right)- \\
\quad\left(\frac{t}{a}+\frac{a}{t}\right)\left(f\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}}\right)-f(1)\right) . \\
\text { Since }\left(a t+\frac{1}{a t}\right)\left(t+\frac{1}{t}\right)-\left(\frac{t}{a}+\frac{a}{t}\right)\left(a^{2} t+\frac{1}{a^{2} t}\right) \\
=a+\frac{1}{a}-\left(a^{3}+\frac{1}{a^{3}}\right)<0,
\end{array}
$$

then $f(t)=c_{1} t+\frac{c_{2}}{t}$,
where $c_{1} „ÄÅ c_{2}$ are expressions in terms of $a „ÄÅ f(1) „ÄÅ f\left(a^{2}\right) „ÄÅ f\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}}\right)$, and do not depend on the variable $t$.
If $f$ is a function of the form (6), then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(x+\frac{1}{x}\right) f(y)=\left(x+\frac{1}{x}\right)\left(c_{1} y+\frac{c_{2}}{y}\right) \\
=\left(c_{1} x y+\frac{c_{2}}{x y}\right)+\left(c_{1} \frac{y}{x}+c_{2} \frac{x}{y}\right) \\
=f(x y)+f\left(\frac{y}{x}\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $f(x)=c_{1} x+\frac{c_{2}}{x}$ is a solution to the original equation (1).
informal_statement:
5. Find all functions $f:(0,+\infty) \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$, such that for all $x, y>0$, we have
$$
\left(x+\frac{1}{x}\right) f(y)=f(x y)+f\left(\frac{y}{x}\right) .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Find all functions $f:(0,+\infty) \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$, such that for all $x, y>0$, we have
$$
\left(x+\frac{1}{x}\right) f(y)=f(x y)+f\left(\frac{y}{x}\right) .
$$ -/
theorem algebra_115742 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : ‚àÄ x > 0, ‚àÄ y > 0, (x + 1 / x) * f y = f (x * y) + f (y / x)) :
    ‚àÉ c1 c2, ‚àÄ x > 0, f x = c1 * x + c2 / x := by

soln_description: n ‚â• 4 Solution It is easy to find counter-examples for n=1,2,3. For example: x(2-x) has p(0) = 0, p(1) = 1, p(2) = 0 x(3-x) has p(0) = 0, p(1) = p(2) = 2, p(3) = 0 x(4-x)(x-2) 2 has p(0) = 0, p(1) = 3, p(2) = 0, p(3) = 3, p(4) = 0 Now suppose n ‚â• 4 and 0 ‚â§ p(k) ‚â§ n for k = 0, 1, ... , n+1. For any polynomial p(n+1) - p(0) must be a multiple of n+1, so in this case p(n+1) must equal p(0). So p(x) - p(0) has factor x(n+1-x) which is > n for x = 2, 3, ... , n-1. Hence p(x) also = p(0) for x = 2, 3, ... , n-1. It remains to consider x = 1, x = n. But p(x) - p(0) must have factor (x-3)(n+1-x) (this is where we need n > 3) and so p(1) - p(0) must have factor 2n > n and hence be zero. p(x) - p(0) also has factor x(n-2-x) (again we need x > 3), so p(n) - p(0) has factor 2n and must be zero. Thanks to Kamil Duszenko 38th IMO shortlist 1997 ¬© John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 2 Dec2003 Last corrected/updated 2 Dec 2003
informal_statement: 38th IMO 1997 shortlist Problem 10 Find all positive integers n such that if p(x) is a polynomial with integer coefficients such that 0 ‚â§ p(k) ‚â§ n for k = 0, 1, 2, ... , n+1 then p(0) = p(1) = ... = p(n+1).

/- 38th IMO 1997 shortlist Problem 10 Find all positive integers n such that if p(x) is a polynomial with integer coefficients such that 0 ‚â§ p(k) ‚â§ n for k = 0, 1, 2, ... , n+1 then p(0) = p(1) = ... = p(n+1). -/
theorem algebra_128836 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n > 0) :
    (‚àÄ p : Polynomial ‚Ñ§, (‚àÄ k ‚àà Finset.Icc 0 (n + 1), 0 ‚â§ p.eval (k : ‚Ñ§) ‚àß p.eval (k : ‚Ñ§) ‚â§ n) ‚Üí
      ‚àÉ x, ‚àÄ k ‚àà Finset.Icc 0 (n + 1), p.eval (k : ‚Ñ§) = x) ‚Üî n ‚â• 4 := by

soln_description:
Solution. Domain of definition: $x \in \mathbf{R}$, since $x^{2}+x+1>0$ for any real $x$. Therefore, the given inequality is equivalent to the inequality

$$
-30 \\
4 x^{2}-(k-3) x+4>0
\end{array}\right.
$$

For the inequalities in the system to be satisfied simultaneously for all $x$, it is necessary and sufficient that the discriminants of the quadratic polynomials on the left sides of the inequalities be negative, i.e., the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
(3+k)^{2}-16=(k+7)(k-1)<0 \\
(k-3)^{2}-64=(k+5)(k-11)<0
\end{array}\right.
$$

must be satisfied. Solving this, we find $k \in[-5 ; 1]$.

Answer: $k \in[-5 ; 1]$.
informal_statement:
5. What should $k$ be so that the inequality

$$

holds for any value of $x$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. What should $k$ be so that the inequality

$$
\left|\frac{x^{2}-k x+1}{x^{2}+x+1}\right|<3
$$

holds for any value of $x$? -/
theorem inequalities_107302 (k : ‚Ñù) :
  (‚àÄ x : ‚Ñù, x^2 + x + 1 ‚â† 0 ‚Üí |(x^2 - k * x + 1) / (x^2 + x + 1)| < 3) ‚Üî
  k ‚àà Icc (-5) 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution. The given inequality is equivalent to the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{x^{2}-5 x+4}{x^{2}-4} \leq 1 \\
\frac{x^{2}-5 x+4}{x^{2}-4} \geqslant-1
\end{array}\right.
$$

The first inequality of the system is equivalent to the inequality

$$
\frac{x-8 / 5}{(x-2)(x+2)} \geqslant 0
$$

Applying the method of intervals, we find its solutions - all numbers from the intervals $-2<x \leqslant 8 / 5$ and $2<x<+\infty$, i.e., the set $(-2 ; 8 / 5] \cup(2 ;+\infty)$.

The second inequality of the system is equivalent to the inequality

$$
\frac{x(x-5 / 2)}{(x+2)(x-2)} \geqslant 0
$$

and, applying the method of intervals again, we find the set of its solutions, consisting of the union of three intervals: $(-\infty ;-2) U$ $U[0 ; 2) \cup[5 / 2 ;+\infty)$.

The intersection of the two obtained sets constitutes the set of solutions to the original inequality, i.e., the set $[0 ; 8 / 5] U[5 / 2 ;+\infty)$.
informal_statement:

theorem inequalities_253614 :

  {x | 0 ‚â§ x ‚àß x ‚â§ 8 / 5 ‚à® 5 / 2 ‚â§ x} := by

informal_statement:
The integer $202020$ is a multiple of $91$. For each positive integer $n$, show how $n$ additional $2$'s may be inserted into the digits of $202020$ such that the resulting $(n+6)$-digit number is also a multiple of $91$. 

For example, a possible way to do this when $n=5$ is [u]2[/u]2020[u]2[/u]20[u]222[/u] (the inserted $2$'s are underlined).

import Mathlib

/- The integer $202020$ is a multiple of $91$. For each positive integer $n$, show how $n$ additional $2$'s may be inserted into the digits of $202020$ such that the resulting $(n+6)$-digit number is also a multiple of $91$. 

For example, a possible way to do this when $n=5$ is [u]2[/u]2020[u]2[/u]20[u]222[/u] (the inserted $2$'s are underlined). -/
theorem number_theory_28459 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 0) :
    91 ‚à£ (202020 + ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range n, 10^i * 2) := by

soln_description:
The mean (average) of the set of six numbers is 10 , and so the sum of the set of six numbers is $6 \times 10=60$.

If the number 25 is removed from the set, the sum of the set of the remaining five numbers is $60-25=35$.

The mean (average) of the remaining set of five numbers is $35 \div 5=7$.

ANsWER: (B)
informal_statement:
The mean (average) of a set of six numbers is 10 . When the number 25 is removed from the set, the mean of the remaining numbers is
(A) 6
(B) 7
(C) 8
(D) 9
(E) 10
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The mean (average) of a set of six numbers is 10 . When the number 25 is removed from the set, the mean of the remaining numbers is
(A) 6
(B) 7
(C) 8
(D) 9
(E) 10 -/
theorem algebra_279664 (S : Finset ‚Ñù) (hS : S.card = 6) (hS1 : ‚àë x ‚àà S, x = 60) (hS2 : 25 ‚àà S) :
    (S \ {25}).card = 5 ‚àß ‚àë x ‚àà (S \ {25}), x = 35 := by

informal_statement: In the arithmetic sequence $\left{ {{a}_{n}} \right}$, if ${{S}_{4}}\leqslant 4, {{S}_{5}}\geqslant 15$, then the minimum value of ${{a}_{4}}$ is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In the arithmetic sequence $\left{ {{a}_{n}} \right}$, if ${{S}_{4}}\leqslant 4, {{S}_{5}}\geqslant 15$, then the minimum value of ${{a}_{4}}$ is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___ -/
theorem algebra_12717 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÉ d, ‚àÄ n, a n = a 0 + d * n)
    (h1 : ‚àë i in Finset.range 4, a i ‚â§ 4) (h2 : ‚àë i in Finset.range 5, a i ‚â• 15) :
    a 4 ‚â• 7 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_12717 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÉ d, ‚àÄ n, a n = a 0 + d * n)
    (h1 : ‚àë i in Finset.range 4, a i ‚â§ 4) (h2 : ‚àë i in Finset.range 5, a i ‚â• 15) :
    a 4 ‚â• 7 := by
  rcases h with ‚ü®d, hd‚ü©

  have h4 : a 4 = a 0 + 4 * d := by 
    specialize hd 4
    rw [hd]
    ring

  have s4 : ‚àë i in Finset.range 4, a i = 4 * a 0 + 6 * d := by 
      simp [Finset.sum_range_succ, hd 1, hd 2, hd 3]
      ring

  have s5 : ‚àë i in Finset.range 5, a i = 5 * a 0 + 10 * d := by 
    simp [Finset.sum_range_succ, hd 1, hd 2, hd 3, hd 4]
    ring
  
  rw [s4] at h1 
  rw [s5] at h2 

  linarith [h1, h2, h4]

formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Let $r$ be a solution of the equation $x^{3}-x+3=0$, then the monic cubic equation with integer coefficients whose solution is $r^{2}$ is $\qquad$

Translate the text above into English, please keep the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly. -/
theorem algebra_252574 {r : ‚Ñù} (hr : r^3 - r + 3 = 0) :
    (X^3 - 2*X^2 + X - 9 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).eval (r^2) = 0 := by

soln_description:
Given $a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c u$. All $a, b, c, u$ are positive, and $ub^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c=(b-c)^{2}$.

From this, we get $|b-c|<a<b+c$.
Therefore, the positive numbers $a, b, c$ can be the lengths of the three sides of a triangle. Let the vertices opposite these sides be $A, B, C$, respectively. By transforming the constraint, we get
$$
u=\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}}{2 b c}=\cos A.
$$

Substituting into the other constraint, we get
$$
a t+b \cos A=c.
$$

Using the projection theorem $c=a \cos B+b \cos A$, we get
$$
t=\cos B.
$$

Since $u$ and $t$ are positive, $\angle A$ and $\angle B$ are acute angles, so,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt{1-u^{2}}=\sqrt{1-\cos ^{2} A}=\sin A, \\
\sqrt{1-t^{2}}=\sqrt{1-\cos ^{2} B}=\sin B.
\end{array}
$$

Let the circumradius of $\triangle ABC$ be $R$, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a=2 R \sin A, b=2 R \sin B, c=2 R \sin C. \\
\begin{aligned}
\therefore W & =\frac{1}{c}\left(\frac{3 a}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{1}-\overline{t^{2}}}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{2 R \sin C}\left(\frac{6 R \sin A}{2}+\frac{2 R \sin B}{\sin B}\right) \\
& =\frac{8 R}{2 R \sin C}=\frac{4}{\sin C} \geqslant 4.
\end{aligned}
\end{array}
$$

The equality holds if and only if $\angle C$ is a right angle, i.e., $a^{2}+b^{2}=c^{2}$. Therefore, the minimum value of $W$ is 4.
informal_statement:
Five. (Full marks 20 points) There is a quantity $W$, after "modeling" the relationship is given by
$$
W=\frac{1}{c}\left(\frac{3 a}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}\right),
$$

where $a, b, c, u, t$ are all positive, $u<1, t<1$, and satisfy $a t+b u=c, a^{2}+2 b c u=b^{2}+c^{2}$. Please design a method to find the minimum value of the quantity $W$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Five. (Full marks 20 points) There is a quantity $W$, after "modeling" the relationship is given by
$$
W=\frac{1}{c}\left(\frac{3 a}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}\right),
$$

where $a, b, c, u, t$ are all positive, $u<1, t<1$, and satisfy $a t+b u=c, a^{2}+2 b c u=b^{2}+c^{2}$. Please design a method to find the minimum value of the quantity $W$. -/
theorem algebra_317644 {a b c u t : ‚Ñù} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
  (hu : 0 < u) (ht : 0 < t) (h : u < 1) (h' : t < 1) (h'' : a * t + b * u = c)
  (h''' : a^2 + 2 * b * c * u = b^2 + c^2) :
  IsLeast {x | ‚àÉ a b c u t : ‚Ñù, 0 < a ‚àß 0 < b ‚àß 0 < c ‚àß 0 < u ‚àß 0 < t ‚àß u < 1 ‚àß t < 1 ‚àß
    a * t + b * u = c ‚àß a^2 + 2 * b * c * u = b^2 + c^2 ‚àß x = (3 * a / sqrt (1 - u^2) + b / sqrt (1 - t^2)) / c} 4 := by

informal_statement: 5. Given 700 different natural numbers, each of which does not exceed 2017. Prove that some two of them differ by 3, 4, or 7.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Given 700 different natural numbers, each of which does not exceed 2017. Prove that some two of them differ by 3, 4, or 7. -/
theorem number_theory_120035 (s : Finset ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : s.card = 700)
    (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àÄ n ‚àà s, n ‚â§ 2017) :
    ‚àÉ m ‚àà s, ‚àÉ n ‚àà s, |(m : ‚Ñ§) - n| = 3 ‚à® |(m : ‚Ñ§) - n| = 4 ‚à® |(m : ‚Ñ§) - n| = 7 := by

soln_description: 2. $00$ always holds, i.e., $\cos 2 \theta-3 \sin \theta+2>2 x-\frac{1}{(x-2)^{2}}$ always holds. Let $g(x)=2 x-\frac{1}{(x-2)^{2}}$, then we have $\cos 2 \theta-3 \sin \theta+2>g(x)_{\max }$. Since $g(x)=2 x-\frac{1}{(x-2)^{2}}=4-\left[(2-x)+(2-x)+\frac{1}{(2-x)^{2}}\right] \leqslant 1$ (when $x=1$), thus $\cos 2 \theta-3 \sin \theta+2>g(x)_{\max }=1, \therefore 2 \sin ^{2} \theta+3 \sin \theta-2<0$, solving it yields $-2<\sin \theta<\frac{1}{2}$. Also, $\sin \theta \geqslant-1$, so $-1 \leqslant \sin \theta<\frac{1}{2}$, and $\theta \in(0, \pi)$. In summary, we get $0<\theta<\frac{\pi}{6}$ or $\frac{5 \pi}{6}<\theta<\pi$.
informal_statement: 2. To make the function $f(x)=\frac{1}{(x-2)^{2}}-2 x+\cos 2 \theta-3 \sin \theta+2$ always positive for $x \in(-\infty, 2)$, the range of the parameter $\theta$ in the interval $(0, \pi)$ is $\qquad$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. To make the function $f(x)=\frac{1}{(x-2)^{2}}-2 x+\cos 2 \theta-3 \sin \theta+2$ always positive for $x \in(-\infty, 2)$, the range of the parameter $\theta$ in the interval $(0, \pi)$ is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_286373 (Œ∏ : ‚Ñù) (hŒ∏ : Œ∏ ‚àà Ioo 0 Real.pi) :
    ‚àÄ x : ‚Ñù, x < 2 ‚Üí 1 / (x - 2)^2 - 2 * x + cos (2 * Œ∏) - 3 * sin Œ∏ + 2 > 0 ‚Üî
    0 < Œ∏ ‚àß Œ∏ < œÄ / 6 ‚à® 5 * œÄ / 6 < Œ∏ ‚àß Œ∏ < œÄ := by

soln_description:
To prove: It is sufficient to prove that among $2d-1$, $5d-1$, and $13d-1$, there must be one that is not a perfect square.
Proof by contradiction.
Suppose all three numbers are perfect squares. Since the sum of two numbers
$$
(2d-1) + (5d-1) + (13d-1) = 20d - 3
$$
is a number of the form $4N + 1$, hence among these three numbers, there must be two even perfect squares and one odd perfect square.

Since $2d-1$ is odd, $5d-1$ and $13d-1$ must both be even perfect squares.

Let $5d-1 = (2a)^2$ and $13d-1 = (2b)^2$. Then $d$ is odd. Thus,
$$
(5d-1)(13d-1) = (4ab)^2,
$$
which means $(9d-1)^2 - (4d)^2 = (4ab)^2$.
Therefore, $d^2 + (ab)^2 = \left(\frac{9d-1}{4}\right)^2$.
Since the left side of the above equation is an integer, $\frac{9d-1}{4}$ must be an integer.
From $9d - 4 \cdot \frac{9d-1}{4} = 1$, we know that $\left(d, \frac{9d-1}{4}\right) = 1$.
Thus, the three numbers $d$, $ab$, and $\frac{9d-1}{4}$ are pairwise coprime, with $d$ being odd.
Therefore, there exist coprime positive integers $m$ and $n$ such that
$$
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
d = m^2 - n^2, \\
\frac{9d-1}{4} = m^2 + n^2.
\end{array}
\right.
$$
Subtracting (1) from (2) gives
$$
2n^2 = \frac{9d-1}{4} - d = \frac{5d-1}{4} = \frac{(2a)^2}{4} = a^2.
$$

The right side of the above equation is a perfect square, while the left side is not, leading to a contradiction.

Therefore, the assumption is false, meaning that among $2d-1$, $5d-1$, and $13d-1$, there must be one that is not a perfect square.
informal_statement: Example 2 Let $d$ be a positive integer not equal to $2, 5, 13$. Prove: in the set $\{2, 5, 13, d\}$, there can be found two distinct elements $a, b$ such that $ab-1$ is not a perfect square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 2 Let $d$ be a positive integer not equal to $2, 5, 13$. Prove: in the set $\{2, 5, 13, d\}$, there can be found two distinct elements $a, b$ such that $ab-1$ is not a perfect square. -/
theorem number_theory_303244 (d : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : d > 0) (h‚ÇÅ : d ‚â† 2) (h‚ÇÇ : d ‚â† 5) (h‚ÇÉ : d ‚â† 13) :
    ‚àÉ a b, (a = 2 ‚àß b = 5) ‚à® (a = 2 ‚àß b = 13) ‚à® (a = 5 ‚àß b = 13) ‚à® (a = d ‚àß b = 2) ‚à®
    (a = d ‚àß b = 5) ‚à® (a = d ‚àß b = 13) ‚àß ¬¨ ‚àÉ m, m^2 = a * b - 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_303244 (d : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : d > 0) (h‚ÇÅ : d ‚â† 2) (h‚ÇÇ : d ‚â† 5) (h‚ÇÉ : d ‚â† 13) :
    ‚àÉ a b, (a = 2 ‚àß b = 5) ‚à® (a = 2 ‚àß b = 13) ‚à® (a = 5 ‚àß b = 13) ‚à® (a = d ‚àß b = 2) ‚à®
    (a = d ‚àß b = 5) ‚à® (a = d ‚àß b = 13) ‚àß ¬¨ ‚àÉ m, m^2 = a * b - 1 := by 
  refine' ‚ü®2, 5, Or.inl ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©‚ü©

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\int_{1}^{64} \frac{1-\sqrt[6]{x}+2 \sqrt[3]{x}}{x+2 \sqrt{x^{3}}+\sqrt[3]{x^{4}}} d x=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=t^{6}, d x=6 t^{5} d t \\
& x=1 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt[6]{1}=1 \\
& x=64 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt[6]{64}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int_{1}^{2} \frac{\left(1-t+2 t^{2}\right) \cdot 6 t^{5} d t}{t^{6}+2 t^{9}+t^{8}}=6 \cdot \int_{1}^{2} \frac{2 t^{2}-t+1}{2 t^{4}+t^{3}+t} d t=
$$

Divide the denominator and numerator by \(2 t^{2}-t+1\):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \begin{array}{ll}
2 t^{4}+t^{3}+t & \mid 2 t^{2}-t+1 \\
\frac{2 t^{4}-t^{3}+t^{2}}{2 t^{3}-t^{2}}+t & t^{2}+t
\end{array} \\
& \frac{2 t^{3}-t^{2}+t}{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =6 \cdot \int_{1}^{2} \frac{1}{t^{2}+t} d t=6 \cdot \int_{1}^{2} \frac{1}{t(t+1)} d t=6 \cdot \int_{1}^{2}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+1}\right) d t= \\
& =\left.6 \cdot(\ln |t|-\ln |t+1|)\right|_{1} ^{2}=6 \cdot(\ln |2|-\ln |2+1|)-6 \cdot(\ln |1|-\ln |1+1|)= \\
& =6 \ln 2-6 \ln 3-6 \cdot 0+6 \ln 2=6 \ln \frac{4}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Source ‚Äî ¬´http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+11-2$ ¬ª

informal_statement:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{1}^{64} \frac{1-\sqrt[6]{x}+2 \sqrt[3]{x}}{x+2 \sqrt{x^{3}}+\sqrt[3]{x^{4}}} d x
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{1}^{64} \frac{1-\sqrt[6]{x}+2 \sqrt[3]{x}}{x+2 \sqrt{x^{3}}+\sqrt[3]{x^{4}}} d x
$$ -/
theorem calculus_127838 : ‚à´ x in (1)..64, (1 - x ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 6) + 2 * x ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3)) / (x + 2 * sqrt (x ^ 3) + x ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3)) = 6 * log (4 / 3) := by

soln_description:
Solution. We will use the method of products. We will compile the calculation table 3. In ¬ß 1 of this chapter, when solving problem 523, it was already indicated how to fill in columns 1-5 of the calculation table, so we will limit ourselves to brief explanations.

To fill in column 6, it is convenient to multiply the numbers of each row of columns 3 and 5. To fill in column 7, it is convenient to multiply the numbers of each row of columns 3 and 6. Column 8 serves to control calculations using the identity

$$
\sum n_{i}\left(u_{i}+1\right)^{4}=\sum n_{i} u_{i}^{4}+4 \sum n_{i} u_{i}^{3}+6 \sum n_{i} u_{i}^{2}+4 \sum n_{i} u_{i}+n
$$

| 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6 | 7 | 8 |
| :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| $x_{i}$ | $n_{i}$ | $u_{i}$ | $n_{i} u_{i}$ | $n i u_{i}^{2}$ | $n i u_{i}^{\mathbf{3}}$ | $n_{i} u_{i}^{4}$ | $n_{i}\left(u_{i}+1\right)^{4}$ |
| 12 | 5 | -2 | -10 | 20 | -40 | 80 | 5 |
| 14 | 15 | -1 | -15 | 15 | -15 | 15 | - |
| 16 | 50 | 0 | -25 | - | -55 | - | 50 |
| 18 | 16 | 1 | 16 | 16 | 16 | 16 | 256 |
| 20 | 10 | 2 | 20 | 40 | 80 | 160 | 810 |
| 22 | 4 | 3 | 12 | 36 | 108 | 324 | 1024 |
|  |  |  | 48 |  | 204 |  |  |
|  | $n=100$ |  | $n_{i} u_{i}=$  $=23$ | $\sum n_{i} u_{i}^{2}$  $=127$ | $\underset{=149}{\sum n_{i} u_{i}^{3}}=$ | $\sum_{=595} n_{i} u_{i}^{4}=$ | $\sum n_{i}\left(u_{i}+\right.$  $+1)^{\prime}=$  $=2145$ |

We will present the calculation table 3.

Table 8

Verification:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum n_{i}\left(u_{i}+1\right)^{4}=2145 \\
& \sum n_{i} u_{i}^{4}+4 \sum n_{i} u_{i}^{3}+6 \sum n_{i} u_{i}^{2}+4 \sum n_{i} u_{i}+n= \\
& =595+4 \cdot 149+6 \cdot 127+4 \cdot 23+100=2145 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The coincidence of the control sums testifies to the correctness of the calculations.

We will find the conditional moments of the third and fourth orders (the conditional moments of the first and second orders were calculated in problem 523: $\left.M_{1}^{*}=0.23, M_{2}^{*}=1.27\right)$ :

$$
M_{3}^{*}=\frac{\sum n_{i} u_{i}^{3}}{n}=\frac{149}{100}=1.49 ; \quad M_{4}^{*}=\frac{\sum n_{i} u_{i}^{4}}{n}=\frac{595}{100}=5.95
$$

We will find the central empirical moments of the third and fourth orders:

$$
\begin{gathered}
m_{3}=\left[M_{3}^{*}-3 M_{1}^{*} M_{2}^{*}+2\left(M_{1}^{*}\right)^{3}\right] h^{3} \\
m_{4}=\left[M_{4}^{*}-4 M_{1}^{*} M_{3}^{*}+6\left(M_{1}^{*}\right)^{2} M_{2}^{*}-3\left(M_{1}^{*}\right)^{4}\right] h^{4}
\end{gathered}
$$

Substituting $h=2$ and $M_{1}^{*}=0.23, M_{2}^{*}=1.27, M_{3}^{*}=1.49, M_{4}^{*}=5.95$, we get $m_{3}=5.104, m_{4}=79.582$.

We will find the required skewness and kurtosis, taking into account that $D_{B}=4.87$ (see problem 523):

$$
\begin{gathered}
a_{s}=m_{3} / \sigma_{B}^{3}=5.124 /(\sqrt{4.87})^{3}=0.47 \\
e_{k}=m_{4} / \sigma_{B}^{4}-3=79.582 /(\sqrt{4.87})^{4}-3=0.36
\end{gathered}
$$
informal_statement:
531. Find the skewness and 9-excess by the method of products for the given sample distribution of size $n=100$:

$$
\begin{array}{lrrrrrrr}
\text { variant } & x_{i} & 12 & 14 & 16 & 18 & 20 & 22 \\
\text { frequency } & n_{i} & 5 & 15 & 50 & 16 & 10 & 4
\end{array}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 531. Find the skewness and 9-excess by the method of products for the given sample distribution of size $n=100$:

$$
\begin{array}{lrrrrrrr}
\text { variant } & x_{i} & 12 & 14 & 16 & 18 & 20 & 22 \\
\text { frequency } & n_{i} & 5 & 15 & 50 & 16 & 10 & 4
\end{array}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_159136 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n = 100) (x : Fin 7 ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hx : x 0 = 12 ‚àß x 1 = 14 ‚àß x 2 = 16 ‚àß x 3 = 18 ‚àß x 4 = 20 ‚àß x 5 = 22)
    (n' : Fin 7 ‚Üí ‚Ñï)
    (hn' : n' 0 = 5 ‚àß n' 1 = 15 ‚àß n' 2 = 50 ‚àß n' 3 = 16 ‚àß n' 4 = 10 ‚àß n' 5 = 4) :
    let a := (n * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) ^ 3 - 3 * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) ^ 2 +
      2 * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) ^ 2) / (n * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) ^ 2 - (‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i)) ^ 2)
    let e := (n * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) ^ 9 - 9 * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) ^ 8 +
      8 * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) ^ 8) / (n * ‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i) ^ 8 - (‚àë i : Fin 7, (x i)) ^ 8)
    a = 0.47 ‚àß e = 0.36 := by

informal_statement: 7. Given a three-digit number $x y z(1 \leqslant x \leqslant 9,0 \leqslant y, z$ $\leqslant 9)$. If $x y z=x!+y!+z!$, then the value of $x+y+z$ is
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Given a three-digit number $x y z(1 \leqslant x \leqslant 9,0 \leqslant y, z$ $\leqslant 9)$. If $x y z=x!+y!+z!$, then the value of $x+y+z$ is -/
theorem number_theory_324818 (x y z : ‚Ñï) (hx : x ‚àà Finset.Icc 1 9) (hy : y ‚àà Finset.Icc 0 9) (hz : z ‚àà Finset.Icc 0 9)
    (h : 100 * x + 10 * y + z = Nat.factorial x + Nat.factorial y + Nat.factorial z) :
    x + y + z = 10 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_324818 (x y z : ‚Ñï) (hx : x ‚àà Finset.Icc 1 9) (hy : y ‚àà Finset.Icc 0 9) (hz : z ‚àà Finset.Icc 0 9)
    (h : 100 * x + 10 * y + z = Nat.factorial x + Nat.factorial y + Nat.factorial z) :
    x + y + z = 10 := by
  have hx1 : x ‚â• 1 := by
    simp [Finset.mem_Icc] at hx
    omega
  have hx2 : x ‚â§ 9 := by
    simp [Finset.mem_Icc] at hx
    omega
  have hy1 : y ‚â• 0 := by
    simp [Finset.mem_Icc] at hy
    omega
  have hy2 : y ‚â§ 9 := by
    simp [Finset.mem_Icc] at hy
    omega
  have hz1 : z ‚â• 0 := by
    simp [Finset.mem_Icc] at hz
    omega
  have hz2 : z ‚â§ 9 := by
    simp [Finset.mem_Icc] at hz
    omega
  interval_cases x <;> interval_cases y <;> interval_cases z <;> try simp [Nat.factorial] at h <;> try { omega }

informal_statement: Evaluate $|(4\sqrt{2}-4i)(\sqrt{3}+3i)|$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Evaluate $|(4\sqrt{2}-4i)(\sqrt{3}+3i)|$ -/
theorem algebra_14860 : Complex.abs (4 * Real.sqrt 2 - 4 * .I) * Complex.abs (Real.sqrt 3 + 3 * .I) = 24 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_14860 : Complex.abs (4 * Real.sqrt 2 - 4 * .I) * Complex.abs (Real.sqrt 3 + 3 * .I) = 24 := by
  have h11 : Complex.abs (4 * Real.sqrt 2 - 4 * Complex.I) = Real.sqrt ((4 * Real.sqrt 2)^2 + (-4 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2) := by
    simp [Complex.abs, Complex.normSq, mul_pow]
    <;> ring_nf
    <;> simp [Complex.I_sq]
    <;> ring_nf
  have h12 : (4 * Real.sqrt 2) ^ 2 + (-4 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 = (48 : ‚Ñù) := by
    nlinarith [Real.sq_sqrt (show 0 ‚â§ (2 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num)]
  have h21 : Complex.abs (Real.sqrt 3 + 3 * Complex.I) = Real.sqrt ((Real.sqrt 3)^2 + (3 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2) := by
    simp [Complex.abs, Complex.normSq, mul_pow]
    <;> ring_nf
    <;> simp [Complex.I_sq]
    <;> ring_nf
  have h22 : (Real.sqrt 3) ^ 2 + (3 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 = (12 : ‚Ñù) := by
    have h3sq : (Real.sqrt 3 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 = 3 := Real.sq_sqrt (by norm_num)
    nlinarith [h3sq]
  have h23 : Real.sqrt ((4 * Real.sqrt 2) ^ 2 + (-4 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2) = Real.sqrt 48 := by
    rw [h12]
  have h24 : Real.sqrt ((Real.sqrt 3) ^ 2 + (3 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2) = Real.sqrt 12 := by
    rw [h22]
  rw [h11, h21]
  rw [h23, h24]
  have h3 : Real.sqrt 48 * Real.sqrt 12 = (24 : ‚Ñù) := by
    calc
      Real.sqrt 48 * Real.sqrt 12 = Real.sqrt (48 * 12) := by
        rw [‚Üê Real.sqrt_mul (by norm_num)]
      _ = Real.sqrt (576 : ‚Ñù) := by norm_num
      _ = (24 : ‚Ñù) := by
        rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
  exact h3

soln_description:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by the equation $y=f(x) ; a \leq x \leq b$ is given by the formula

$$
L=\int_{a}^{b} \sqrt{1+\left(f^{\prime}(x)\right)^{2}} d x
$$

Let's find the derivative of the given function:

$$
f^{\prime}(x)=\left(\frac{1-e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(-e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)
$$

Then, using the formula above, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{1+\frac{1}{4} \cdot\left(-e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)^{2}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{4+\left(-e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)^{2}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{4+e^{2 x}-2+e^{-2 x}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{e^{2 x}+2+e^{-2 x}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)^{2}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3}\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right) d x= \\
& =\left.\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x}-e^{-x}\right)\right|_{0} ^{3}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\left(e^{3}-e^{0}\right)-\left(e^{-3}-e^{0}\right)\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{3}-e^{-3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Source ‚Äî ¬´http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+17-31$ ¬ª Categories: Kuznetsov's Problem Book Integrals Problem 17 | Integrals

informal_statement:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by equations in a rectangular coordinate system.

$$
y=\frac{1-e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2}, 0 \leq x \leq 3
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- ## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by equations in a rectangular coordinate system.

$$
y=\frac{1-e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2}, 0 \leq x \leq 3
$$ -/
theorem calculus_139253 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (hf : f = Œª x => (1 - exp x - exp (-x)) / 2) :
  ‚à´ x in (0)..3, sqrt ((deriv f x)^2 + 1) = (exp 3 - exp (-3)) / 2 := by

soln_description:
[Proof] Let $f(v)=g(v) 2^{v^{2}}$, then the given recurrence relation becomes
$$\begin{array}{l}
g(v+2)-2 g(v+1)+g(v)=v 16^{-v-1} \\
\quad v=0,1,2, \cdots .
\end{array}$$

Summing the above equation from 0 to $v-1$, we get
$$g(v+1)-g(v)=\frac{1}{15^{2}}\left[1-(15 v+1) \cdot 16^{-v}\right]$$

Summing again (from 0 to $v-1$), we obtain
$$g(v)=\frac{1}{15^{3}}\left[15 v-32+(15 v+2) 16^{-v+1}\right],$$

thus
$$\begin{array}{c}
f(v)=\frac{1}{15^{3}}\left[15 v+2+(15 v-32) 16^{v-1}\right] 2^{(v-2)^{2}} \\
(v=0,1,2, \cdots)
\end{array}$$

Taking modulo 13, we get
$$\begin{aligned}
& 15 v+2+(15 v-32) 16^{v} 1 \\
\equiv & 2 v+2+(2 v-6) 3^{v-1} \\
\equiv & 2\left(v+1+(v-3) 3^{v-1}\right)(\bmod 13)
\end{aligned}$$

Since
$$1990 \equiv 1(\bmod 13), 3^{3} \equiv 1(\bmod 13)$$

Therefore, for $v=1989,1990,1991$ we have
$$f(v) \equiv 0(\bmod 13)$$
informal_statement:
$$\begin{array}{l}
6 \cdot 23 \text { Let } f(0)=f(1)=0 \text {, and } \\
f(v+2)=4^{v+2} f(v+1)-16^{v+1} f(v)+v 2^{v^{2}},(v=0,1,2, \cdots) .
\end{array}$$

Prove: $f(1989), f(1990), f(1991)$ are all divisible by 13

import Mathlib

/- $$\begin{array}{l}
6 \cdot 23 \text { Let } f(0)=f(1)=0 \text {, and } \\
f(v+2)=4^{v+2} f(v+1)-16^{v+1} f(v)+v 2^{v^{2}},(v=0,1,2, \cdots) .
\end{array}$$

Prove: $f(1989), f(1990), f(1991)$ are all divisible by 13 -/
theorem number_theory_597210 {f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§}
    (h0 : f 0 = 0) (h1 : f 1 = 0)
    (hf : ‚àÄ v, f (v + 2) = 4^(v + 2) * f (v + 1) - 16^(v + 1) * f v + v * 2^(v^2)) :
    13 ‚à£ f 1989 ‚àß 13 ‚à£ f 1990 ‚àß 13 ‚à£ f 1991 := by

soln_description:
1. **Identify the roots and the polynomial:**
   Given the polynomial \( P(x) = x^5 - x^2 + 1 \) with roots \( r_1, r_2, r_3, r_4, r_5 \), we need to find the value of the product \( Q(r_1)Q(r_2)Q(r_3)Q(r_4)Q(r_5) \) where \( Q(x) = x^2 + 1 \).

2. **Express the product in terms of the roots:**
   We need to evaluate:
   \[
   \prod_{i=1}^{5} Q(r_i) = \prod_{i=1}^{5} (r_i^2 + 1)
   \]

3. **Simplify the product:**
   Notice that:
   \[
   \prod_{i=1}^{5} (r_i^2 + 1) = \prod_{i=1}^{5} Q(r_i)
   \]
   Since \( Q(x) = x^2 + 1 \), we can rewrite the product as:
   \[
   \prod_{i=1}^{5} (r_i^2 + 1)
   \]

4. **Evaluate \( P(i) \) and \( P(-i) \):**
   Plugging \( x = i \) and \( x = -i \) into \( P(x) \):
   \[
   P(i) = i^5 - i^2 + 1 = i - (-1) + 1 = i + 2
   \]
   \[
   P(-i) = (-i)^5 - (-i)^2 + 1 = -i - (-1) + 1 = -i + 2
   \]

5. **Multiply \( P(i) \) and \( P(-i) \):**
   \[
   P(i) \cdot P(-i) = (i + 2)(-i + 2)
   \]
   Simplify the product:
   \[
   (i + 2)(-i + 2) = (i)(-i) + 2(-i) + 2(i) + 2^2 = -i^2 - 2i + 2i + 4 = 1 + 4 = 5
   \]

6. **Conclusion:**
   Therefore, the value of the product \( Q(r_1)Q(r_2)Q(r_3)Q(r_4)Q(r_5) \) is:
   \[
   \boxed{5}
   \]
informal_statement: Given that the polynomial $P(x) = x^5 - x^2 + 1$ has $5$ roots $r_1, r_2, r_3, r_4, r_5$. Find the value of the product $Q(r_1)Q(r_2)Q(r_3)Q(r_4)Q(r_5)$, where $Q(x) = x^2 + 1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given that the polynomial $P(x) = x^5 - x^2 + 1$ has $5$ roots $r_1, r_2, r_3, r_4, r_5$. Find the value of the product $Q(r_1)Q(r_2)Q(r_3)Q(r_4)Q(r_5)$, where $Q(x) = x^2 + 1$. -/
theorem algebra_62374 {P Q : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ} (hP : P = fun x => x^5 - x^2 + 1)
    (hQ : Q = fun x => x^2 + 1) (r : Fin 5 ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) (hr : ‚àÄ i, P (r i) = 0) :
    Q (r 0) * Q (r 1) * Q (r 2) * Q (r 3) * Q (r 4) = 5 := by

soln_description:
To show that the coefficients of a binomial expansion $(a+b)^n$ are all odd if and only if $n$ is of the form $2^k - 1$ for some positive integer $k$, we will use properties of binomial coefficients and properties of numbers in binary representation.

1. **Binomial Coefficients and Parity**:
   The binomial expansion of $(a+b)^n$ is given by:
   \[
   (a+b)^n = \sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} a^{n-k} b^k
   \]
   The coefficients $\binom{n}{k}$ are the binomial coefficients. We need to determine when all these coefficients are odd.

2. **Properties of Binomial Coefficients**:
   A binomial coefficient $\binom{n}{k}$ is odd if and only if there is no carry in the binary addition of $k$ and $n-k$. This is a consequence of Lucas' Theorem, which states that:
   \[
   \binom{n}{k} \equiv \prod_{i=0}^{m} \binom{n_i}{k_i} \pmod{p}
   \]
   where $n_i$ and $k_i$ are the digits of $n$ and $k$ in base $p$, and $p$ is a prime. For $p=2$, $\binom{n}{k}$ is odd if and only if each $\binom{n_i}{k_i}$ is odd, which happens if and only if $k_i \leq n_i$ for all $i$.

3. **Binary Representation**:
   For $\binom{n}{k}$ to be odd for all $k$, the binary representation of $n$ must be such that every bit is 1. This is because if $n$ has a 0 in its binary representation, there will be some $k$ such that $k_i > n_i$, making $\binom{n_i}{k_i} = 0$ (even).

4. **Form of $n$**:
   A number $n$ with all bits as 1 in binary is of the form $2^k - 1$. For example:
   - $1 = 2^1 - 1$ (binary: 1)
   - $3 = 2^2 - 1$ (binary: 11)
   - $7 = 2^3 - 1$ (binary: 111)
   - $15 = 2^4 - 1$ (binary: 1111)
   - and so on.

5. **Conclusion**:
   Therefore, $n$ must be of the form $2^k - 1$ for some positive integer $k$ for all binomial coefficients $\binom{n}{k}$ to be odd.
informal_statement: Show that the coefficients of a binomial expansion $(a+b)^n$ where $n$ is a positive integer, are all odd, if and only if $n$ is of the form $2^{k}-1$ for some positive integer $k$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that the coefficients of a binomial expansion $(a+b)^n$ where $n$ is a positive integer, are all odd, if and only if $n$ is of the form $2^{k}-1$ for some positive integer $k$. -/
theorem number_theory_68432 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 0) :
    (‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range (n + 1), Odd (Nat.choose n i)) ‚Üî
    ‚àÉ k > 0, n = 2 ^ k - 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution: Let $N=(2 k+1)+(2 k+3)+\cdots+(2 k+2 n-1)$ where $n$ and $k$ are integers, $n \geq 2, k \geq 0$. Then $N=[(2 k+1)+(2 k+2 n-1)] n / 2=(2 k+n) n$, which is a product of two integers with the same parity, since adding the even number $2 k$ to the integer $n$ does not change its parity.
1. Since $2005=401 \cdot 5$, taking $n=5$ gives $2 k+5=401$, i.e. $2 k+1=397$. Checking, we see that $397+399+401+403+405=401 \cdot 5=2005$, so 2005 can be represented as the sum of at least two consecutive odd positive integers.
2. Since $2006=2 \cdot 1003=2 \cdot 17 \cdot 59$ is divisible by 2 but not by 4 , every pair of integers with a product of 2006 consists of two integers with different parity, (i.e. one odd and one even). Therefore 2006 cannot be represented as the sum of at least two consecutive odd positive integers.
informal_statement:
2 Since $24=3+5+7+9$, the number 24 can be written as the sum of at least two consecutive odd positive integers.
(a) Can 2005 be written as the sum of at least two consecutive odd positive integers? If yes, give an example of how it can be done. If no, provide a proof why not.
(b) Can 2006 be written as the sum of at least two consecutive odd positive integers? If yes, give an example of how it can be done. If no, provide a proof why not.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2 Since $24=3+5+7+9$, the number 24 can be written as the sum of at least two consecutive odd positive integers.
(a) Can 2005 be written as the sum of at least two consecutive odd positive integers? If yes, give an example of how it can be done. If no, provide a proof why not.
(b) Can 2006 be written as the sum of at least two consecutive odd positive integers? If yes, give an example of how it can be done. If no, provide a proof why not. -/
theorem number_theory_247428 :
    ‚àÉ n, Odd n ‚àß Odd (n + 2) ‚àß 2005 = n + (n + 2) ‚àß
    ‚àÉ m, Odd m ‚àß Odd (m + 2) ‚àß 2006 = m + (m + 2) := by

soln_description:
1. We start with the given conditions: \(a < b \leq c < d\), \(ad = bc\), and \(\sqrt{d} - \sqrt{a} \leq 1\).

2. From the inequality \(\sqrt{d} - \sqrt{a} \leq 1\), we can square both sides to obtain:
   \[
   (\sqrt{d} - \sqrt{a})^2 \leq 1^2 \Rightarrow d - 2\sqrt{ad} + a \leq 1 \Rightarrow a + d \leq 1 + 2\sqrt{ad}
   \]

3. Suppose first that \(\sqrt{d} - \sqrt{a} = 1\). Then:
   \[
   d - 2\sqrt{ad} + a = 1 \Rightarrow a + d = 1 + 2\sqrt{ad}
   \]

4. Since \(ad = bc\), we substitute \(ad\) with \(bc\):
   \[
   a + d = 1 + 2\sqrt{bc}
   \]

5. Given \(a < b \leq c < d\), we know \(a + d \geq b + c + 1\). Therefore:
   \[
   1 + 2\sqrt{bc} \leq b + c + 1 \Rightarrow 2\sqrt{bc} \leq b + c
   \]

6. Squaring both sides, we get:
   \[
   4bc \leq (b + c)^2 \Rightarrow 4bc \leq b^2 + 2bc + c^2 \Rightarrow 0 \leq b^2 - 2bc + c^2 \Rightarrow 0 \leq (b - c)^2
   \]

7. Since \((b - c)^2 \geq 0\) is always true, equality holds if and only if \(b = c\). Thus:
   \[
   b = c
   \]

8. Substituting \(b = c\) into \(ad = bc\), we get:
   \[
   ad = b^2
   \]

9. Since \(a + d = 2b + 1\) and \(ad = b^2\), we need to show that \(a\) is a perfect square. Assume \(\gcd(a, d) = 1\). If \(p\) is a prime divisor of both \(a\) and \(d\), then \(p\) divides \(b\), leading to a contradiction because \(p\) cannot divide \(2b + 1\). Therefore, \(a\) and \(d\) must be coprime, implying both \(a\) and \(d\) are perfect squares.

10. Now, suppose \(\sqrt{d} - \sqrt{a} < 1\). Then:
    \[
    a + d < 1 + 2\sqrt{ad} \leq 1 + b + c \leq a + d
    \]
    This leads to a contradiction, as \(a + d\) cannot be less than or equal to itself.

Thus, we have shown that \(a\) must be a perfect square.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
One considers the positive integers $a < b \leq c < d $ such that $ad=bc$ and $\sqrt d  - \sqrt a \leq 1 $. 

Prove that $a$ is a perfect square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- One considers the positive integers $a < b \leq c < d $ such that $ad=bc$ and $\sqrt d  - \sqrt a \leq 1 $. 

Prove that $a$ is a perfect square. -/
theorem number_theory_89903 {a b c d : ‚Ñï} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d)
    (hord : a < b ‚àß b ‚â§ c ‚àß c < d) (hmul : a * d = b * c) (hdiff : Real.sqrt d - Real.sqrt a ‚â§ 1) :
    ‚àÉ m, m^2 = a := by

soln_description:
5. $(37,74)$.

To make the equation hold, we need to consider the values of trigonometric functions at special angles.
Observe $\cos \frac{\pi y}{2 x}$.
When $y=2 x$, $\cos \frac{\pi y}{2 x}=\cos \pi=-1$. Let's experiment with the original equation by setting $y=2 x$.
The left side $=\sqrt{x} \cos \frac{2 x \pi}{2 x}+\sqrt{2 x} \sin \frac{x \pi}{2 \times 2 x}$
$=\sqrt{x} \cos \pi+\sqrt{2 x} \sin \frac{\pi}{4}$
$=-\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{2 x} \times \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}=0=$ right side.
This exactly satisfies the requirement $\sqrt{x} \cos \frac{\pi y}{2 x}+\sqrt{y} \sin \frac{\pi x}{2 y}=0$.
Let $x+y=111$. Thus, $x=37, y=74$.
Therefore, a pair of natural numbers $(x, y)$ that meet the conditions of the problem is $(37,74)$.
informal_statement:
5. Two natural numbers $x$ and $y$ sum to 111, such that the equation
$$
\sqrt{x} \cos \frac{\pi y}{2 x}+\sqrt{y} \sin \frac{\pi x}{2 y}=0
$$

holds. Then a pair of natural numbers $(x, y)$ that satisfies the condition is
$\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Two natural numbers $x$ and $y$ sum to 111, such that the equation
$$
\sqrt{x} \cos \frac{\pi y}{2 x}+\sqrt{y} \sin \frac{\pi x}{2 y}=0
$$

holds. Then a pair of natural numbers $(x, y)$ that satisfies the condition is
$\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_303685 (x y : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : x + y = 111) (h‚ÇÅ : Real.sqrt x * Real.cos (Real.pi * y / (2 * x)) + Real.sqrt y * Real.sin (Real.pi * x / (2 * y)) = 0) :
    x = 37 ‚àß y = 74 := by

soln_description:
Since $f_{i}(x)$ is an even function, and for any real number $x$, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f_{i}(x+\pi)=f_{i}(x) \Rightarrow f_{i}(-x+\pi)=f_{i}(-x)=f_{i}(x), i=1,2,3,4 . \\
\text { Thus }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
f(x)=f_{1}(x)+f_{2}(x) \cos x+f_{3}(x) \sin x+f_{4}(x) \sin 2 x, \\
f(-x)=f_{1}(x)+f_{2}(x) \cos x-f_{3}(x) \sin x-f_{4}(x) \sin 2 x, \\
f(\pi-x)=f_{1}(x)-f_{2}(x) \cos x+f_{3}(x) \sin x-f_{4}(x) \sin 2 x, \\
f(\pi+x)=f_{1}(x)-f_{2}(x) \cos x-f_{3}(x) \sin x+f_{4}(x) \sin 2 x .
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}
$$
(1) + (2) + (3) + (4) $\Rightarrow f_{1}(x)=\frac{f(x)+f(-x)+f(\pi-x)+f(\pi+x)}{4}$;
(1) + (2) $\Rightarrow f_{2}(x) \cos x=\frac{f(x)+f(-x)}{2}-f_{1}(x)$
$=\frac{f(x)+f(-x)-f(\pi-x)-f(\pi+x)}{4}$ $\Rightarrow f_{2}(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\frac{f(x)+f(-x)-f(\pi-x)-f(\pi+x)}{4 \cos x}, & x \neq k \pi+\frac{\pi}{2}, \\ 0, & x=k \pi+\frac{\pi}{2} ;\end{array}\right.$
(1) + (3) $\Rightarrow f_{3}(x) \sin x=\frac{f(x)+f(\pi-x)}{2}-f_{1}(x)$
$\begin{aligned}= & \frac{f(x)-f(-x)+f(\pi-x)-f(\pi+x)}{4} \\ & \Rightarrow f_{3}(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\frac{f(x)-f(-x)+f(\pi-x)-f(\pi+x)}{4 \sin x}, & x \neq k \pi, \\ 0, & x=k \pi ;\end{array}\right.\end{aligned}$
(1) + (4) $\Rightarrow f_{4}(x) \sin 2 x=\frac{f(x)+f(\pi+x)}{2}-f_{1}(x)$
$=\frac{f(x)-f(-x)-f(\pi-x)+f(\pi-x)}{4}$
$\Rightarrow f_{4}(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\frac{f(x)-f(-x)-f(\pi-x)+f(\pi+x)}{4 \sin 2 x}, & x \neq \frac{k \pi}{2}, \\ 0, & x=\frac{k \pi}{2} .\end{array}\right.$
Since $f_{1}(x+\pi)=\frac{f(x+\pi)+f(-x-\pi)+f(-x)+f(2 \pi+x)}{4}$
$=\frac{f(\pi+x)+f(\pi-x)+f(-x)+f(x)}{4}=f_{1}(x)$;
When $x \neq k \pi+\frac{\pi}{2}$, $f_{2}(x+\pi)=\frac{f(\pi+x)+f(\pi-x)-f(-x)-f(x)}{-4 \cos x}=f_{2}(x)$;
When $x \neq k \pi$, $f_{3}(x+\pi)=\frac{f(\pi+x)-f(\pi-x)+f(-x)-f(x)}{-4 \sin x}=f_{3}(x)$;
When $x \neq \frac{k \pi}{2}$, $f_{4}(x+\pi)=\frac{f(\pi+x)-f(\pi-x)-f(-x)+f(x)}{4 \sin 2 x}=f_{4}(x)$.
It is easy to verify that $f_{i}(x), i=1,2,3,4$ satisfy the other conditions. Therefore, the conclusion holds.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 15. Let the function $f(x)$ satisfy $f(x+2\pi)=f(x)$ for all real numbers $x$. Prove: There exist 4 functions $f_{i}(x) (i=1,2,3,4)$ that satisfy:
(1) For $i=1,2,3,4$, $f_{i}(x)$ is an even function, and for any real number $x$, $f_{i}(x+\pi)=f_{i}(x)$;
(2) For any real number $x$, $f(x)=f_{1}(x)+f_{2}(x) \cos x+f_{3}(x) \sin x+f_{4}(x) \sin 2 x$. -/
theorem algebra_250405 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : ‚àÄ x, f (x + 2 * Real.pi) = f x) :
    ‚àÉ f1 f2 f3 f4 : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù,
      Even f1 ‚àß Even f2 ‚àß Even f3 ‚àß Even f4 ‚àß
      ‚àÄ x, f1 (x + Real.pi) = f1 x ‚àß f2 (x + Real.pi) = f2 x ‚àß
      f3 (x + Real.pi) = f3 x ‚àß f4 (x + Real.pi) = f4 x ‚àß
      ‚àÄ x, f x = f1 x + f2 x * Real.cos x + f3 x * Real.sin x + f4 x * Real.sin (2 * x) := by

soln_description:
Solution. The members of the sequence are divided into groups as follows: there is one member whose sum of the numerator and denominator is 2, there are two members of the sequence whose sum of the numerator and denominator is 3, there are three members of the sequence whose sum of the numerator and denominator is 4, etc. There are $n$ members whose sum of the numerator and denominator is $n+1$. The fraction $\frac{2014}{2015}$ has a sum of 4029. This means that before it, there are

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+2+3+\ldots+4027 & =(1+4026)+(2+4025)+\ldots+(2013+2014)+4027 \\
& =2014 \cdot 4027 \\
& =8110378
\end{aligned}
$$

members whose sum of the numerator and denominator is less than 4029. In the last group with the sum of 4029, before the desired fraction are the numbers $\frac{4028}{1}, \frac{4027}{2}, \frac{4026}{3}, \frac{4025}{4}, \ldots, \frac{2014}{2015}$. Therefore, the fraction $\frac{2014}{2015}$ is located at

$$
8110378+2014+1=8112393 \text { position. }
$$

## IX Department

theorem number_theory_242995 : (Nat.nth {x | ‚àÉ m n, x = m / n ‚àß m > 0 ‚àß n > 0} 8112392) = 2014 / 2015 := by

soln_description:
2.5. Let the pair of numbers $x, y \in \mathbf{Z}$ satisfy the equation, then $x^{2}+2 x y+y^{2}=x^{2} y^{2}+x y$, i.e., $(x+y)^{2}=x y(x y+1)$.

If $x y>0$, then

$$
x y+1>\sqrt{x y(x y+1)}>x y
$$

$$
|x+y|=\sqrt{x y(x y+1)}
$$

lies between two consecutive integers $x y$ and $x y+1$, and thus cannot be an integer. Similarly, if $x y<-1$, then

$$
-x y-1<\sqrt{x y(x y+1)}<-x y
$$

and thus the number $|x+y|$ cannot be an integer again. Therefore, we have either $x y=0$ or $x y=-1$. In both cases, the equation is equivalent to the equality $x+y=0$, so either $x=y=0$, or $x=-y= \pm 1$ respectively. Thus, we get the answer: $(0 ; 0),(1 ;-1),(-1 ; 1)$.
informal_statement:

soln_description:
9. Solution The original inequality can be transformed into $\left(\cos x-\frac{a-1}{2}\right)^{2} \leqslant a^{2}+\frac{(a-1)^{2}}{4}$.

Since $-1 \leqslant \cos x \leqslant 1, a<0, \frac{a-1}{2}<0$,
when $\cos x=1$, the function $y=\left(\cos x-\frac{a-1}{2}\right)^{2}$ has the maximum value $\left(1-\frac{a-1}{2}\right)^{2}$, thus we have $\left(1-\frac{a-1}{2}\right)^{2} \leqslant a^{2}+\frac{(a-1)^{2}}{4}$, simplifying gives $a^{2}+a-2 \geqslant 0$, so $a \geqslant 1$ or $a \leqslant-2$, and since $a<0$, we have $a \leqslant-2$.

informal_statement: Find the value of $x,$ if \[|x-20| + |x-18| = |2x-36|.\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the value of $x,$ if \[|x-20| + |x-18| = |2x-36|.\] -/
theorem algebra_11970 {x : ‚Ñù} (h : abs (x - 20) + abs (x - 18) = abs (2 * x - 36)) : x = 19 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_11970 {x : ‚Ñù} (h : abs (x - 20) + abs (x - 18) = abs (2 * x - 36)) : x = 19 := by
  have h1 : abs (2 * x - 36) = 2 * abs (x - 18) := by
    calc
      abs (2 * x - 36) = abs (2 * (x - 18)) := by ring_nf
      _ = abs (2) * abs (x - 18) := by rw [abs_mul]
      _ = 2 * abs (x - 18) := by norm_num
  rw [h1] at h
  have h2 : abs (x - 20) = abs (x - 18) := by linarith
  cases abs_eq_abs.1 h2 with
  | inl h3 =>
      linarith
  | inr h4 =>
      linarith

soln_description:
(1) $a^{2}+b^{2}+T=a^{2}+b^{2}+(a+b)(c+d)+a b+c d$
$$\begin{array}{l}
\geqslant 2 a b+2 \sqrt{a b} \cdot 2 \sqrt{c d}+a b+c d \\
=4+3 a b+c d \geqslant 4+2 \cdot \sqrt{3 a b c d} \\
=4+2 \sqrt{3}
\end{array}$$

When $a=b, c=d, 3 a b=c d$, i.e., $a=b=\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{\frac{1}{t}}, c=d=3^{\frac{1}{4}}$, the equality holds.
Therefore, the minimum value of $a^{2}+b^{2}+T$ is $4+2 \sqrt{3}$.
(2)
$$\begin{aligned}
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+T & =a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+(a+b+c) d+a b+b c+c a \\
& \geqslant 3 \sqrt[3]{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}+3 \sqrt[3]{a b c} \cdot d+3 \cdot \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{2}} \\
& =3 \cdot\left[2 \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{2}}+\sqrt[3]{a b c} \cdot d\right] \\
& \geqslant 3 \cdot 2 \cdot \sqrt{2 \sqrt[3]{(a b c)^{2}} \cdot \sqrt[3]{a b c} \cdot d} \\
& =6 \sqrt{2}
\end{aligned}$$

The equality holds when $a=b=c=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}, d=2^{\frac{3}{4}}$.
Therefore, the minimum value of $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+T$ is $6 \sqrt{2}$.

open Real Set

(2) Find the minimum value of $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+T$. -/

    (h : a * b * c * d = 1) :

    a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 + (a * (b + c + d) + b * (c + d) + c * d) ‚â• 4 + 2 * sqrt 3 := by

$$
a_{n}=C_{200}^{n} \cdot(\sqrt[3]{6})^{200-n} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{n}=C_{200}^{n} \cdot 3^{\frac{200-n}{3}} \cdot 2^{\frac{400-5 n}{6}} \text {, }
$$

When $\frac{200-n}{3}, \frac{400-5 n}{6}$ are both integers, it is found that $n=6 k-4$.
Combining $n \leqslant 95 \Rightarrow k=1,2, \cdots, 16$, since $k=15,16 \Rightarrow n=86,92$.
$a_{86}=C_{200}^{86} \cdot 3^{38} \cdot 2^{-5}=\frac{200!}{86!\cdot 114!} \cdot 3^{38} \cdot 2^{-5}$, where the power of 2 in 200! is $\left[\frac{200}{2}\right]+\left[\frac{200}{2^{2}}\right]+\cdots+\left[\frac{200}{2^{7}}\right]=197,86$! The power of 2 in 86! is $\left[\frac{86}{2}\right]+\left[\frac{86}{2^{2}}\right]+\cdots+\left[\frac{86}{2^{6}}\right]$ $=82,114$! The power of 2 in 114! is $\left[\frac{114}{2}\right]+\left[\frac{114}{2^{2}}\right]+\cdots+\left[\frac{114}{2^{6}}\right]=110$.
Thus, the power of 2 in $C_{200}^{86}$ is $197-82-110=5$, so $a_{86}$ is an integer. $a_{92}=C_{200}^{92} \cdot 3^{36} \cdot 2^{-10}=\frac{200!}{92!\cdot 108!} \cdot 3^{36} \cdot 2^{-10}$, where the power of 2 in 92! is $\left[\frac{92}{2}\right]+\left[\frac{92}{2^{2}}\right]+\cdots+\left[\frac{92}{2^{6}}\right]=88,108$! The power of 2 in 108! is $\left[\frac{108}{2}\right]+\left[\frac{108}{2^{2}}\right]+\cdots+\left[\frac{108}{2^{6}}\right]$ $=104$. Thus, the power of 2 in $C_{200}^{92}$ is $197-88-104=5$, so $a_{92}$ is not an integer. In summary, the number of integer terms in the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is 15.
informal_statement: 8. Given $a_{n}=C_{200}^{n} \cdot(\sqrt[3]{6})^{200-n} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{n}(n=1,2, \cdots, 95)$, the number of integer terms in the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is $\qquad$.

soln_description: 25. D Let $n$ be the total number of passengers in the middle two carriages. These are the ninth and tenth carriages and so, since there are 199 passengers in any block of five adjacent carriages, the total number of passengers in the sixth, seventh and eighth carriages is $199-n$. There are 199 passengers in total in carriages 1 to 5 inclusive, in carriages 9 to 13 inclusive and in carriages 14 to 18 inclusive. Since there are 700 passengers in total on the train, we have $199+199-n+199+199=700$. Therefore $796-n=700$ and hence $n=96$. Therefore there are 96 passengers in total in the middle two carriages of the train.
informal_statement:
25. A train is made up of 18 carriages. There are 700 passengers travelling on the train. In any block of five adjacent carriages, there are 199 passengers in total. How many passengers in total are in the middle two carriages of the train?
A 70
–í 77
–° 78
D 96
E 103

E 103 -/

    (h' : ‚àë i, a i = 700) :
    a 8 + a 9 = 96 := by

How many students showed up to the archery class this week?

soln_description:
To find the smallest possible value of \( |(\cot A + \cot B)(\cot B + \cot C)(\cot C + \cot A)| \) in a triangle \( ABC \), we will use the properties of cotangent and the angles in a triangle.

1. **Express cotangent in terms of sine and cosine:**
   \[
   \cot A = \frac{\cos A}{\sin A}, \quad \cot B = \frac{\cos B}{\sin B}, \quad \cot C = \frac{\cos C}{\sin C}
   \]

2. **Use the identity for the sum of angles in a triangle:**
   \[
   A + B + C = \pi
   \]

3. **Express the product \( (\cot A + \cot B)(\cot B + \cot C)(\cot C + \cot A) \):**
   \[
   (\cot A + \cot B)(\cot B + \cot C)(\cot C + \cot A)
   \]

4. **Use the cotangent addition formula:**
   \[
   \cot(A + B) = \frac{\cot A \cot B - 1}{\cot A + \cot B}
   \]
   Since \( A + B + C = \pi \), we have \( \cot C = -\cot(A + B) \).

5. **Simplify the expression:**
   \[
   (\cot A + \cot B)(\cot B + \cot C)(\cot C + \cot A) = (\cot A + \cot B)(\cot B - \cot(A + B))(\cot(A + B) + \cot A)
   \]

6. **Use the identity for the product of cotangents in a triangle:**
   \[
   \cot A \cot B + \cot B \cot C + \cot C \cot A = 1
   \]

7. **Substitute and simplify:**
   \[
   (\cot A + \cot B)(\cot B + \cot C)(\cot C + \cot A) = (\cot A + \cot B)(\cot B - \cot(A + B))(\cot(A + B) + \cot A)
   \]
   Using the identity \( \cot A \cot B + \cot B \cot C + \cot C \cot A = 1 \), we can simplify further.

8. **Find the minimum value:**
   The minimum value occurs when \( A = B = \frac{\pi}{3} \) and \( C = \frac{\pi}{3} \). In this case:
   \[
   \cot \frac{\pi}{3} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}
   \]
   \[
   (\cot \frac{\pi}{3} + \cot \frac{\pi}{3})(\cot \frac{\pi}{3} + \cot \frac{\pi}{3})(\cot \frac{\pi}{3} + \cot \frac{\pi}{3}) = \left( \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \right)^3 = \frac{8}{3\sqrt{3}} = \frac{8\sqrt{3}}{9}
   \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{\frac{8\sqrt{3}}{9}} \).
informal_statement: In triangle $ABC$, find the smallest possible value of $$|(\cot A + \cot B)(\cot B +\cot C)(\cot C + \cot A)|$$

    A + B + C = œÄ ‚àß x = abs ((cot A + cot B) * (cot B + cot C) * (cot C + cot A))} (8 * sqrt 3 / 9) := by

5. B From $f(x+999)=-\frac{1}{f(x)}$ we get $f(x+1998)=-\frac{1}{f(x+999)}$, which means $f(1998+x)=f(x)$, so $y=$ $f(x)$ is a periodic function with a period of 1998,
because $f(x)=f(1998+x)=f[999+(999+x)]$
$$
=f[999-(999+x)]=f(-x) \text {. }
$$

That is, $f(-x)=f(x)$, so $y=f(x)$ is an even function. Therefore, the answer is B.

A. is an odd function but not an even function
B. is an even function but not an odd function
C. is both an odd function and an even function
D. is neither an odd function nor an even function

soln_description:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\text { Proof: To prove the original inequality, we need to show: } \\
\sum \frac{a(a+b+c)}{b^{2}+c^{2}}-\frac{2 a}{b+c} \geq 0 \Leftrightarrow \sum\left[\frac{a b(a-b)+(a-c) a c}{\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(b+c)}\right]+\sum \frac{2 a b c}{\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(b+c)} \geq 0 \\
\Leftrightarrow \sum \frac{(a-b)^{2} a b\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+a b+a c+b c+c^{2}\right)}{\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(b+c)\left(a^{2}+c^{2}\right)(a+c)}+\sum \frac{2 a b c}{\left(b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(b+c)} \geq 0
\end{array}$$

The inequality is clearly true. In fact, this inequality is not difficult, even easier to prove than a similar one 19.
This inequality can be generalized to:
$$\left(\sum \frac{a^{m}}{b^{m+n}+c^{m+n}}\right) \cdot\left(\sum a^{n}\right) \geq 2 \cdot \sum \frac{a^{m}}{b^{m}+c^{m}} \geq 2 \cdot \sum \frac{a}{b+c} \quad\left(m, n \in R_{+}, \quad m, n \geq 1\right)$$

To prove the left inequality, the method is similar to the above (thus not detailed); for the right inequality, please refer to the generalization $\mathbf{1}$
informal_statement:
Strengthening 7 We seek intrinsic connections similar to Nesbitt's inequality, obtained through the MAPLE software, if \(a, b, c \in R_{+}\), then (the coefficient 2 is the strongest case):
$$2 \cdot \sum \frac{a}{b+c} \leq (a+b+c) \sum \frac{a}{b^{2}+c^{2}}$$

import Mathlib

/- Strengthening 7 We seek intrinsic connections similar to Nesbitt's inequality, obtained through the MAPLE software, if \(a, b, c \in R_{+}\), then (the coefficient 2 is the strongest case):
$$2 \cdot \sum \frac{a}{b+c} \leq (a+b+c) \sum \frac{a}{b^{2}+c^{2}}$$ -/
theorem inequalities_599582 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    2 * (a / (b + c)) + 2 * (b / (c + a)) + 2 * (c / (a + b)) ‚â§
    (a + b + c) * (a / (b ^ 2 + c ^ 2)) + (a + b + c) * (b / (c ^ 2 + a ^ 2)) +
    (a + b + c) * (c / (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2)) := by

soln_description:
6.4. The equation $a^{x}=x^{b}$ is equivalent to the equation $c^{x}=x$, where $c=a^{1 / b}>1$. Since the derivative of the function $f(x)=c^{x}-x$, which is $f^{\prime}(x)=c^{x} \ln c-1$, is positive when $c^{x}>\log _{c} e$ and negative when $c^{x}<\log _{c} e$, there exists a unique $x_{0}>0$ that satisfies the equation $c^{x_{0}}=\log _{c} e$. If $f\left(x_{0}\right)>0$, then the original equation has no solutions; if $f\left(x_{0}\right)=0$, then the equation has a unique positive solution $x=x_{0}$; if $f\left(x_{0}\right)<0$, then the equation has two positive solutions (since $f(0)=-1<0$ and $\left.\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x)=\infty\right)$.

Thus, the original equation meets the problem's requirements if and only if $x_{0}=c^{x_{0}}=\log _{c} e_{\mathrm{1}}$, i.e., $x_{0}=c^{\log _{c} e}=e$ and $c=e^{1 / e}$.

Therefore, the sought values of $a, b$ (and only they) satisfy the equation $a^{e}=e^{b}$, where $b>0$, i.e., $a=t, b=e \ln t$, where $t \in(1 ; \infty)$, and the unique positive solution of the equation is $x=$.

soln_description: 4. Let the equation of the hyperbola be $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1(a>0, b>0)$. Since $\frac{b}{a}=\sqrt{e^{2}-1}=\frac{4}{3}$, we can set $a^{2}=9 \lambda, b^{2}=16 \lambda(\lambda>$ 0 ), so the equation of the hyperbola is $\frac{x^{2}}{9 \lambda}-\frac{y^{2}}{16 \lambda}=1$. Because the line $8 x+2 \sqrt{7} y-16=0$ is tangent to it, by property 5, we have $64 \cdot 9 \lambda-28 \cdot 16 \lambda=16^{2}$, which gives $\lambda=2$, hence the equation of the hyperbola is $\frac{x^{2}}{18}-\frac{y^{2}}{32}=1$.
informal_statement: 4. Given that the center of the hyperbola is the origin, the foci are on the $x$-axis, the eccentricity $e=\frac{5}{3}$, and it is tangent to the line $8 x+2 \sqrt{7} y-16=0$. Find the equation of the hyperbola.

soln_description:
To prove that for any integer \( a \) there exist infinitely many positive integers \( n \) such that \( a^{2^n} + 2^n \) is not a prime, we can proceed as follows:

1. **Case for \( a = 0 \) and \( a = 1 \):**
   - For \( a = 0 \):
     \[
     0^{2^n} + 2^n = 2^n
     \]
     Since \( 2^n \) is not a prime for \( n \geq 2 \) (as \( 2^n \) is a power of 2 and greater than 2), there are infinitely many \( n \) such that \( 0^{2^n} + 2^n \) is not a prime.
   - For \( a = 1 \):
     \[
     1^{2^n} + 2^n = 1 + 2^n
     \]
     For \( n \geq 2 \), \( 1 + 2^n \) is not a prime because it is an even number greater than 2.

2. **Case for \( |a| \geq 2 \):**
   - Consider \( n = 2m \) where \( m \) is an odd positive integer.
   - We can rewrite \( a^{2^n} + 2^n \) as follows:
     \[
     a^{2^n} + 2^n = a^{2^{2m}} + 2^{2m}
     \]
     Using the identity for the sum of squares:
     \[
     a^{2^{2m}} + 2^{2m} = (a^{2^m})^2 + (2^m)^2
     \]
     This can be factored as:
     \[
     a^{2^{2m}} + 2^{2m} = (a^{2^m} + 2^m)^2 - 2^{m+1}a^{2^m}
     \]
   - Since \( m \) is odd, \( 2^{m+1}a^{2^m} \) is even and thus \( (a^{2^m} + 2^m)^2 - 2^{m+1}a^{2^m} \) is not a prime for sufficiently large \( m \).

3. **Conclusion:**
   - For any integer \( a \), there exist infinitely many positive integers \( n \) such that \( a^{2^n} + 2^n \) is not a prime.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Prove that for any integer $a$ there exist infinitely many positive integers $n$ such that $a^{2^n}+2^n$ is not a prime.

[b]proposed by S. Berlov[/b]

soln_description:
the fraction $\dfrac{1}{99}$ can be written as \[\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}\dfrac{1}{10^{2n}}\].
similarly the fraction $\dfrac{1}{99^2}$ can be written as $\sum^{\infty}_{m=1}\dfrac{1}{10^{2m}}\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}\dfrac{1}{10^{2n}}$ which is equivalent to \[\sum^{\infty}_{m=1}\sum^{\infty}_{n=1} \dfrac{1}{10^{2(m+n)}}\]
and we can see that for each $n+m=k$ there are $k-1$ $(n,m)$ combinations so the above sum is equivalent to:
\[\sum^{\infty}_{k=2}\dfrac{k-1}{10^{2k}}\]
we note that the sequence starts repeating at $k = 102$
yet consider \[\sum^{101}_{k=99}\dfrac{k-1}{10^{2k}}=\dfrac{98}{{10^{198}}}+\dfrac{99}{{10^{200}}}+\dfrac{100}{10^{{202}}}=\dfrac{1}{10^{198}}(98+\dfrac{99}{100}+\dfrac{100}{10000})=\dfrac{1}{10^{198}}(98+\dfrac{99}{100}+\dfrac{1}{100})=\dfrac{1}{10^{198}}(98+\dfrac{100}{100})=\dfrac{1}{10^{198}}(99)\]
so the decimal will go from 1 to 99 skipping the number 98
and we can easily compute the sum of the digits from 0 to 99 to be \[45\cdot10\cdot2=900\] subtracting the sum of the digits of 98 which is 17 we get
\[900-17=883\textbf{(B) }\qquad\]

Proof: From equation (18) in ¬ß2, we have
$$\begin{aligned}
1 & =\sum_{n \leqslant x}\left[\frac{1}{n}\right]=\sum_{n \leqslant x} \sum_{d \mid n} \mu(d)=\sum_{\substack{d \leqslant x \\
d \geqslant 1, l \geqslant 1}} \mu(d) \\
& =\sum_{d \leqslant x} \mu(d) \sum_{1 \leqslant l \leqslant x / d} 1=\sum_{d \leqslant x} \mu(d)\left[\frac{x}{d}\right]
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, we have
$$x \sum_{d \leqslant x} \frac{\mu(d)}{d}=1-\sum_{d \leqslant x} \mu(d)\left\{\frac{x}{d}\right\}$$

From this and
$$\left|1-\sum_{d \leqslant x} \mu(d)\left\{\frac{x}{d}\right\}\right|=\left|1-\{x\}-\sum_{2 \leqslant d \leqslant x} \mu(d)\left\{\frac{x}{d}\right\}\right| \leqslant x$$

we derive equation (35). Proof completed.

soln_description: 12.5. Suppose there exist coprime natural numbers $m$ and $n$ such that $m n(m+n)(m-n)=s^{2}$, where $s$ is a natural number. We will assume that $s$ is the smallest number for which such an equality holds. The numbers $m, n, m+n, m-n$ are pairwise coprime, so $m=x^{2}$, $n=y^{2}$, $m+n=z^{2}$, and $m-n=t^{2}$, where $x, y, z$, and $t$ are natural numbers. The numbers $m$ and $n$ have different parities, so the numbers $z$ and $t$ are odd. Let $A=\frac{z+t}{2}$ and $B=\frac{z-t}{2}$. Then $A^{2}+B^{2}=\frac{z^{2}+t^{2}}{2}=m=x^{2}$ and $\frac{A B}{2}=\frac{z^{2}-t^{2}}{8}=\frac{n}{4}=\frac{y^{2}}{4}$. Thus, for the number $y / 2$, the same equality holds. Therefore, $y^{2} \geqslant 4 s^{2}$, i.e., $y^{2} \geqslant 4 x^{2} y^{2}\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)$. This leads to a contradiction.

/- 2. If the planar vectors $\vec{a}=\left(2^{m},-1\right)$ and $\vec{b}=\left(2^{m}-1,2^{m+1}\right)$ are perpendicular, where $m$ is a real number, then the magnitude of $\vec{a}$ is . $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_284630 (m : ‚Ñù) (a b : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù)
    (ha : a = (2 ^ m, -1)) (hb : b = (2 ^ m - 1, 2 ^ (m + 1)))
    (h : a.1 * b.1 + a.2 * b.2 = 0) :
    Real.sqrt (a.1 ^ 2 + a.2 ^ 2) = Real.sqrt 10 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_284630 (m : ‚Ñù) (a b : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù)
    (ha : a = (2 ^ m, -1)) (hb : b = (2 ^ m - 1, 2 ^ (m + 1)))
    (h : a.1 * b.1 + a.2 * b.2 = 0) :
    Real.sqrt (a.1 ^ 2 + a.2 ^ 2) = Real.sqrt 10 := by 
  rw [ha, hb] at h
  have h_eq : (2:‚Ñù) ^ m * (2 ^ m - 1) + (-1) * (2 ^ (m + 1)) = 0 := by 
    simpa using h
  have h1 : (2:‚Ñù) ^ (m + 1) = (2:‚Ñù) ^ m * 2 := by 
    rw [Real.rpow_add]
    norm_num
    all_goals linarith 
  rw [h1] at h_eq 
  have h3 : (2:‚Ñù) ^ m * (2 ^ m - 3) = 0 := by 
    nlinarith 
  have h4 : (2:‚Ñù) ^ m > 0 := by 
    positivity 
  have h5 : (2:‚Ñù) ^ m - 3 = 0 := by 
    nlinarith [h3, h4] 
  have h6 : (2:‚Ñù) ^ m = 3 := by 
    linarith 
  rw [ha]
  have h8 : ((2:‚Ñù) ^ m) ^ 2 + (-1:‚Ñù) ^ 2 = 10 := by 
    rw [h6] 
    norm_num 
  rw [h8]
  all_goals norm_num

soln_description:
9.4. Yana has at least one card, say $k \neq 1$. If Ivo has 1 , then the product $1 . k=k$ does not belong to Yana, a contradiction. Therefore Yana has 1 .

If 12 is in Ivo, then the sum $13=1+12$ belongs to Yana, a contradiction. Therefore 12 belongs to Yana. Since the sum $13=6+7$ is in Ivo, both cards 6 and 7 belong to one and the same person. They are not in Ivo since otherwise the sum $1+6=7$ is in Yana. Using similar arguments we conclude that all cards $1,2, \ldots, 12$ belong to Yana. Further, all cards $13 k, k=1, \ldots, 7$, are in Ivo, and all the others belong to Yana. Therefore Yana has $100-7=93$ cards.
informal_statement:
Problem 9.4. Ivo writes consecutively the integers $1,2, \ldots, 100$ on 100 cards and gives some of them to Yana. It is known that for every card of Ivo and every card of Yana, the card with the sum of the numbers on the two cards is not in Ivo and the card with the product of these numbers is not in Yana. How many cards does Yana have if the card with number 13 is in Ivo?

Ivailo Kortezov
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 9.4. Ivo writes consecutively the integers $1,2, \ldots, 100$ on 100 cards and gives some of them to Yana. How many cards does Yana have if the card with number 13 is in Ivo?

Ivailo Kortezov -/
theorem number_theory_296080 (I Y : Finset ‚Ñï) (hI : I ‚äÜ Finset.Icc 1 100)
    (hY : Y ‚äÜ Finset.Icc 1 100) (hY1 : ‚àÄ x ‚àà Y, ‚àÄ y ‚àà I, x + y ‚àâ I)
    (hY2 : ‚àÄ x ‚àà Y, ‚àÄ y ‚àà I, x * y ‚àâ Y) (hY3 : 13 ‚àà I) :
    Y.card = 93 := by

soln_description:
Obviously, $a \neq 1$ must hold, because for $a=1$ the three equations would coincide and thus the system would be indeterminate. Adding the three equations, we get $(a+2)(x+y+z)=1+a+a^{2}$. Clearly, $a \neq -2$ must hold, as $a=-2$ leads to the contradiction $0=3$. Given $a+2 \neq 0$, this equation is equivalent to

$$
x+y+z=\frac{1+a+a^{2}}{a+2}
$$

Subtracting this equation from each equation of the given system, we obtain (with $a$ real, $a \neq 1, a \neq -2$)

$$
x=-\frac{a+1}{a+2} ; \quad y=\frac{1}{a+2} ; \quad z=\frac{(a+1)^{2}}{a+2}
$$

Let $a$ be a real number. Solve the following system of equations in real numbers $x, y, z$. Which values of $a$ are excluded?

$$
\begin{array}{r}
a x+y+z=1 \\
x+a y+z=a \\
x+y+a z=a^{2}
\end{array}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_161416 (a : ‚Ñù) :
    ¬¨‚àÉ x y z, a * x + y + z = 1 ‚àß x + a * y + z = a ‚àß x + y + a * z = a ^ 2 ‚Üî

soln_description:
The answer is all $n$ other than $1,2,3,5$.
Claim - The only solution with $n \leq 5$ is $n=4$.

Proof. The case $n=4$ works since $2+2=2 \cdot 2=4$. So assume $n>4$.
We now contend that $k>2$. Indeed, if $a_{1}+a_{2}=a_{1} a_{2}=n$ then $\left(a_{1}-a_{2}\right)^{2}=$ $\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)^{2}-4 a_{1} a_{2}=n^{2}-4 n=(n-2)^{2}-4$ is a rational integer square, hence a perfect square. This happens only when $n=4$.

Now by AM-GM,
$$
\frac{n}{k}=\frac{a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}}{k} \geq \sqrt[k]{a_{1} \ldots a_{k}}=n^{1 / k}
$$
and so $n \geq k^{\frac{1}{1-1 / k}}=k^{\frac{k}{k-1}}$. This last quantity is always greater than 5 , since
$$
\begin{aligned}
3^{3 / 2} & =3 \sqrt{3}>5 \\
4^{4 / 3} & =4 \sqrt[3]{4}>5 \\
k^{\frac{k}{k-1}} & >k \geq 5 \quad \forall k \geq 5 .
\end{aligned}
$$

This finishes the proof.
Now, in general:
- If $n \geq 6$ is even, we may take $\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n / 2}\right)=(n / 2,2,1, \ldots, 1)$.
- If $n \geq 9$ is odd, we may take $\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{(n-3) / 2}\right)=(n / 2,1 / 2,4,1, \ldots, 1)$.
- A special case $n=7$ : one example is $(4 / 3,7 / 6,9 / 2)$. (Another is $(7 / 6,4 / 3,3 / 2,3)$.)

Remark. The main hurdle in the problem is the $n=7$ case. One good reason to believe a construction exists is that it seems quite difficult to prove that $n=7$ fails.
informal_statement: Find all positive integers $n$ for which there exist an integer $k \geq 2$ and positive rational numbers $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{k}$ satisfying $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{k}=a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{k}=n$.

theorem number_theory_248363 (n : ‚Ñï) :
